reviewText:
Star Conflict is a third person space combat game. The game currently features some PvP, PvE and PvAI scenarios. You get to pick one of three factions, Jericho, Federation and Empire, each with unique stats on their ships.
The combat in Star Conflict feels solid, there's always bullets, plasma, lasers and rockets flying in all directions, and it's ships do not fly like Star Wars, as they fly like planes in space, here ships can remain still, move in all directions without limitations. You get to pick one of three ship types at first, Interceptor, Fighter and Frigate, from smallest to biggest.
The game itself puts heavy focus on team work. PvE Missions and PvP requires some co-ordination with your team. Truth be told, when a team works together they are unstoppable.

My favorite type of ships are the Fighters, and it's role Tacklers, focusing mostly on throwing de-buffs and cloacking behind enemy lines.

This game is to be experienced with friends and comrades, and if you need someone to guide you, let me know, In-game my nick is Richyda.

PS: If you wish, use this code to be my refferal, we both gain Galactic Standards from it, which is ingame currency.
D42BF26E5AFF755DBE6571472126F2A7 Use it just when you are about to select your starting faction, thanks!

reviewText:
I played this game for nearly 1500 hours using game launcher and if don't believe me, check my achievements. There is no way you can get them in an hour or a day or even a week.

Developers say it is a team game, but unfortunately it is not. In fact it punishes you for being in group with a friend, increasing your queue time dramatically. If there is no any other group to place against you, just forget about battle.

Open space is very limited and boring. Randomly generated quests are basically 3 types: kill a thing or many things, protect the transport, fly to to another thing and activate/pickup it, and activating and picking it up is the same action to be honest. Some of daily quests there are too difficult for a single person, but you will never find anyone to help you because as said above, there is no reason to team up, unless you want to wait half a day to enter pvp battle.

Want to give developers feedback or report a bug on their forum? Dont forget to add how great their game is, any negative feed back will be wiped out in minutes.

I really want to recommend this game but i can't.

reviewText: Until the devs fix their servers, this game is a huge pile of crap for any North American player.  Expect massive ping on any server that isn't US, and sometimes even on US servers.  I have played for two years now, purchased all the DLC, and put a lot of time and effort, but yet their servers are still a steaming pile of dog crap.  I am near the point of just giving up (not a rage post, I've been playing for 2 years and it is still bad).  This is the only thing holding this game back from becoming a very VERY fun FTP game.\n\nOther than the absolute garbage servers, the game is amazing.  Visually awesome, good gameplay, and generally a fun experience as you level up.  If you are EU or RU player, go for it, but as for me and anyone else in North America, steer clear.

reviewText:
Star Conflict is a 3D PvP arcade space shooter made by Russian devs, with plenty of progression to go through, and a typically smooth difiiculty curve. It's been an excellent time sink for me, with a great concept with wonderful graphics (that still runs pretty nicely - with the exception of one map - on integrated graphics if turned down a tad) and a neat community that has its own quirks. As it's free, if anyone asked me whether or not to give it a go, I'd say absolutely. That's not that it doesn't have its problems, though.

Perhaps the worst of these is the blatant monetization. It was less apparent when I started, probably a combination both of more monetization as you progress and more monetization as time went on, but at this point, it's practically screaming for money. There's myriad kinds of in game currency, eight of which are free, and one of which is premium. The primary currency, credits, is earned by simply playing - neat enough. But six of the remaining require you to do certain tasks while playing, many of which are extremely difficult. Even if you do complete some, these tasks are then put on cooldown for some value of time between nothing - for the lowest paying ones - or 17 hours - for the highest. Complicating matters further, one can only earn two of these six at a time, and must pay roughly 20 minutes worth of credits to change which two - or skimp out and pay with premium. These six currencies are used to pay for certain equipment upgrades, which can also be skimped out on and paid with premium. The other free currency not yet talked about is perhaps the only one in abundance that doesn't really encourage anyone to skip out and pay with premium for.

The premium problem does go a bit further, yes, but not that much. There exist premium ships in the game, and while they typically have a slight advantage - easier progression, no upkeep fees, the tiniest of extra customization, get in the same queue as a slightly lower ranked free ship - they're not honestly that great. I've used one myself, and heard from several veteran players that they're not that much better, and in some cases, are even slightly worse than their free counterparts. Premium currency can be used for the things mentioned in the paragraph above, but those are mostly convenience fees, albeit convenience" in the sense of "how it should have been done in the first place because the system is a tad bit too grindy for most people". But perhaps the biggest travesty is that customization of ships - and I'm not talking about buying passive modules and such - is so ridiculous. To buy a colour
date: one must pay roughly a dollar's worth of real world money. Each ship has three colours
hoursPlayed: so to fully customize a ship

reviewText:
I've played Star Conflict extensively during the Open Beta, then in Sporadic but long bouts for another two years afterwards, being active in the forum in the beginning, observing changes, giving input, being ignored-----.


Now then.
You can essentially tackle the entire  game in two ways:

You can either get premium ships, equipment, a guild spot and a freaking battleship, spending all your lollars on the way,
OR you can despair over it, grind out your sorry ♥♥♥, having to make do with savagely inferior equipment most of the time, like I did.

...At least I became a rather decent dogifghter that way.

You can either move to Russia, learn russian while you're at it -for the guild spot, I mean- and, ALLEGEDLY, get at least a handful of games with short waiting times and no disconnects.
OR you can despair over it, Wondering what on earth has you getting 10+ Minute wait times, 15 disconnects and seemingly scheduled server timeouts despite your state-of-the-art fiber-wire internet connection (4k porn? puh-lease...), like I did.

...At least I got to see the last 30 seconds of the match, though usually my absence caused my team to lose.

You can either join one of the slim handful of dev-lobbying (also Russian) guilds (Sorry, Corporations".) by throwing money at them so they can enlarge their D's (I'M TALKING ABOUT DREADNOUGHTS YOU PERVERT!)
OR you can go solo

reviewText:
This game has its good sides and bad sides.

First of all, the handling of the ship is absolutely perfect, there are a lot of games that could learn a thing or two about fluid controls from this game. The ships handling is fast, responsive, easy to learn, and will allow you to move your ship more or less any way you would want to.

Second, the quality of the graphics is very high, I would even go as far as saying they are beautiful. The last space game that I played was freelancer, and this game totally blows freelancer out of the water when it comes to the graphics.

Third, the overall layout is intuitive and easy to understand. You will have no problem at all figuring out where you go to get new weapons, or what you have to click to go do missions, everything is layed out in a simple but good looking interface.

However, the game suffers from that DLC nonsense we have all seen time and time again, and has other problems too.

The biggest problem for me, is how generic everything is, it has a serious lack of personality. While the graphics are beautiful, they are beautiful graphics of generic looking things. Generic space stations, generic ships, generic races/factions, generic everything.

The whole game, feels like it was put together by highly competent and passionate developers, who were forced into doing things the way the suited business men wanted it done. Namely, DLC and stuff.

To me, it feels like a game that was made to fit a business model, instead of a business model made to fit a game. In other words, I think the idea to make money from a space game came before the idea to make a space game with this one.

The second biggest problem, is that if you want to go PVP, or PVE, you have to wait to join some seperate instance thing. This procedure can take as much as a minute or two, and it causes the game to feel fragmented. Personally, I would preffer a large open space to explore, rather than lots of seperate instances to load.

Overall, considering how much choice there is out there, I would not recommend this game.

Having said that, it is totally free to download and play, and you don't really have anything to lose. The file is a few gig, and there will be an update after, so maybe leave it downloading and installing over night, and give it a try the next morning.

5/10 that could so easy be a 10/10 with some tweeking.

reviewText:
Despite the promising teasers and exciting premise of a proper space dogfighting experience, I feel Star Conflict falls short of delivering a flat out entertaining experience. There exists a double edged sword when it comes to offering a free to play title along with paid content. On one edge, you've got the semblance of a fully enjoyable well balanced title. Obversely, there is that nasty temptation of paying to bypass grinding or paying to compete with other paid players. Star Conflict is no stranger to this system, and offers the payment option quite often, as many times as it can. Whether this be through pop ups offering deals on standards, or through post match reminders along the lines of 'this is how much you COULD have earned if you were premium.' I may be biased towards the F2P format for games, but when it's that in your face, it gets quite frustrating.

Admittedly, SC is not without it's fun. At it's core it's a very pretty, smooth running game. There is plenty of visual candy to keep your attention focused on combat. PvE is an excellent alternative to dodge the paid players in PvP, and is done well enough that it's not inherently obvious you're playing against bots. They mostly consist of strike type missions mixed with capturing points. This is one of the few redeeming features I see, aside from other basic, but desperately needed additions such as a daily log in bonus (after five days, a free player can get 24 hours of premium status). Honestly, PvP can be avoided altogether if one absolutely wanted to. You get a decent amount of credits in the beginning to buy a few ships, but I started to notice the ships were getting more and more expensive when climbing the level tree. The daily login bonus coupled with the PvE missions were keeping me afloat and able to pay for ammunition after every match, but any more ships, and I feel I would start getting credit starved. This is where the curve starts to kick in, and it becomes ever more tempting to buy into the game to continue your progress. Progression is choked further when attempting to sell ships and recover some credits for the next level ship; I received a quote of exactly 1 credit when attempting to sell my used gunship. Not sure if this is just because it's a low tier ship, or because you genuinely get no credits for used ships. Thus, you are forced back into the same PvE mission to grind for more credits.

Due to how heavily insistent the game is on purchasing credits, I cannot recommend this game to any serious player. At most, a few hours of fun can be had from progressing a few levels and playing through several PvE matches. Heck, you may even play a few very one sided, poorly matched PvP matches against high tier players too. Play the game for a bit, get what fun you can out of it, and leave once it stops being fun. Just don't spend any money on it, and you can leave guilt free.

reviewText:
Edit: I'm rewritting this review, since there has been some changes after I wrote the original one.

I've been playing this game for more than one year and I think I can give you a balanced review.

First of all: This game is not Star Citizen, or Eve Online or Elite Dangerous. It doesn't want to be either.

This game is a lobby based, free to play fighting arena game, settled in space. You have several ships at your disposal, with different classes and a lot of modules and modifiers to customize their performance. Then you go into battle in teams against other people in several game modes like the usual team battle, king of the hill, capture points etc... So far really standard.

We can say that it is very similar to Warthunder of World of tanks, but with spaceships regarding the pvp skirmish matches.

Then you have also High end content for clans with rewards if you conquer some of the sectors, which is nice for hardcore players, since you can even win a few premium currency here and there.

NEW!: High end content has been reworked and now you can battle other corporations with your own corporate dreadnought. The attacks and defences are all happening in the open world map, so it is all integrated in the same place, instead of random sectors as it was before. So far it looks nice and helps with immersion. Dread battles feel like a mashup of all modes, since you have beacons (dread tactical devices) bombs, and a lot of tactical choices. The battle feels gorgeous and I remember in the first 2 or 3 games I was just watching the new graphics instead of playing.

The only problem so far is that most of the corporations just fight over the small sectors, and the tier 4 were contested in the first week and since they they haven't changed. I suppose with time more and more people will join the fray. But the tier 3 sectors are really, really contested.

And finally, what makes this game very balanced is that you can also play missions or scenarios in a Co-op fashion with friends, or straight open world and do PvP (pilot killing) or PvE vs AI.

The open world is not like Eve online, is more like a huge sandbox map, with some RPG like missions (go there, kill 4 wolfs, come back, go there, pick some asteroids and return) and people to interact with. But you have respawns and you don't lose your stuff if you are killed, so it is more arcadish.

Good thing is that the open world comes with a simple manufacturing tab which allows you to manufacture special ammo, weapons and consumables with the resources collected in there, and also 3 top tier ships which can be configured as you want when you are building them.

The business model is akin to said games (warthunder, world of tanks) so you have to play and unlock ships with experience, credits and several special currency to get better and better modules. Investing money in the game gives you economical advance, as it is usual in this games, but so far there is nothing you can get with gold that you can't get for free. You will just have it later.

Concerning most of the complains about the pay to win in premium ships, premium ships are not better than standard ships. They have the same slots than their credit counterparts, and the bonus are different, but not better. Modules can be shared between ships so there is no difference either.

The problem is that in the tech tree, the credit ships appear with their level 1 stats, and premiums always appear with full level, because they are sold that way. But after you level your credit ships you will see that the premium ships are not better.

So my final verdict is still a 9, because the Dreadnoughts are still in developing (not tier 5 Dreads yet) but we are almost there. All other balance issues with the new consumables had been fixed, and currently only the Destructor weapon is a pain in high tier beacon games. But I hope they will fix it as well.

PROS:
- Good art and graphics.
- Runs well in mid and low end computers.
- Free to play, it won't hurt your wallet if you try it.
- Fast paced action and a good number of game modes.
- PvP, PvE, and a sandbox with both, all in the same game.
- SPACE DUDE!! SPACE!!!

CONS:
- A good chunk of the population is russian, so expect longer than average waiting times out of russian or european prime time.
- Servers are a bit unstable sometimes, but this is something I'm finding in almost any late game.
- Population is not as high as in mainstream games like world of tanks or warthunder. You won't notice it in low - mid tiers, but top end content lacks a bit of players.

reviewText:
Smooth graphic engine, precision control over your ship & weapons, all packaged up with fun skirmish mode of gameplay. Although the game modes are limited at the moment, the core game is solid with plenty of ships & items to unlock or buy. Mechanics also implemented for character/faction progression which also in-turn adds more customisation options. The netcode is really good resulting in a positive multiplayer online experience.

Is it a MMO .. No, are the DLCs good value .. No, but try it for free & buy some in-game credits for boosters .. the rest you can quickly earn in battle! If you are a fan of space sims, sci-fi or competitive gameplay check this out.


If you enjoyed reading this review, please follow True Blue Reviews for more recommendations!

reviewText:
With the start of Season 2 and the exciting arrival of dreadnoughts for inter-corporation battles, I decided I would finally write a review for this awesome game, to which I have devoted a large part of my life for the past year (you decide if that is a good thing or a bad thing ;) ).

First of all, why is it a good game?

Beautiful graphics: ships maps and backgrounds (tip: press Alt+H in-battle to remove the HUD)

PVP, PVE and Invasion (open world) game modes

Large variety of maps in all game modes

Hundreds of fully customisable ships, with many different types of modules

Corperations - the game's clans system

It's FREE TO PLAY!!! and definitely not pay to win - all premium ships only offer small advantages over their non-premium counterparts, if any at all

What is wrong with the game? (it has to be mentioned, despite my love for the game...)

Fairly small matches in higher tiers

Low population on anything other than EU/RU prime time

High ping for US pilots on RU servers and vice versa

High grind, but hey? who want a game you can complete in two days?  Also there are plenty of ways to reduce grind by using real money, if that is what you are looking for.

Previously I would have said lack of communication on the dev's behalf, but this seems to have changed recently

Difficulty to get matches in squads, since with the current system, a squad of the same size as yours has to queue up also, before you can get into a match.

Some tips for someone trying the game for the first time:

Please try the game until tier 3 (ranks 7-9) at least.  This will give you the best overall view of the game, as t3 is where you get the largest PVP matches, and where most of the intercorporate tournaments happen.

Join a corp as soon as you reach t2/t3, and ask around for a corp that uses voice comms.  You can easily find one on the forum.  Joining a corp will help you make friends, and make the most out of the game.  They can give you advice, ship builds, squad with you, and just generally have a good laugh together!

The forum has a lot of information. Get involved! Ask questions and the game's veterans will be glad to help you! (maybe your thread will turn into a huge off-topic debate, but that's another matter...)

Try all ship types from all factions, before you choose your favourites.  They all have very different playing styles!

PVE can be very useful to gain credits rapidly, while PVP is better for synergising (levelling-up) your ships.

Watch out in Invasion, there are pilots like mysself lurking around ;) If you just want to farm bots, don't forget to put your station protection on before undocking.  Also don't forget that certain zones have no station protection.

I look forward to meeting you on the battlefield! GL and may the biomorphs leave you unmolested!

reviewText:
From the moment I started to play Star Conflict I fell in love with the game. It was full of potential and possibilities. Different classes of ships, great PvP and awesome massive space battles.
Unfortunately all those possibilities went down the drain.

Now, Star Conflict is unbalanced, boring , tedious , pay to win PvP with shallow story and grind mode. PVE is repititive, PvP matchmaking is horrible and open space (Invasion,) well, bland boring.

Dreadnoughts are just another game mode made without imagination and creativity.

If you like space game you should definitely try this game, you will either love it or hate it. If you wanna save your nerves avoid this game, comepletly.

My score of this game in it's current state  is 45/100.

reviewText:
Take the negative reviews for this game witn a grain of salt, look at all the positives (86% positive for this game)! I haven't seen any bad administrating or admin abuse in this game in all the hours I have played, but I have heard that the GMs run a tight ship & don't put up with nonsense as in other games (like racists rants in-game or use of foul language in chat), so these are probably just people who got a timeout for spamming the n-word, or a hateful clan taking out their anger. In fact the devs put on fun special events that anyone can participate in & you will get great prizes & they are really nice, even giving new players tips & advice no matter what country you are from.

The game isn't grindy at all, if you are an average player you can probably unlock a different ship each day in just a few hours of play & each ship comes fully loaded with a free set of weapons & modules so it's ready for battle. Compared to other free to play games the grind is miniscule, & with each step your ship & your whole fleet gets more & more powerful, any reviewer who says this game is a grind obviously hasn't played many free-to-play games.

It's not a pay-to-win game at all, what you can buy as for DLC packages doesn't make you better & the ships you can unlock in-game & the custom ships you can build in-game are either on par with the premium ships or in most cases even more powerful than the premium ships you can buy. So why do people buy the premium & DLC packages? Well it's very simple, would you rather play a lot, or pay a little to progress a little faster (this is the same as all the other free-to-play games out there). If you have a job you might be willing to spend some money to support the game & get some cool looking ships/ decals/ & extra synnergy gain. If you don't want to spend the dough then just play more & you're on par with all the players that have bought something (how do you think the company will make the game & manage it without some sort of transactions taking place?).

Also they give free premium money (Galactic Standards) away all the time for answering in-game questionaires (like which ship do you like best?, etc.), They give free premium money away EVEN FOR COMPLETEING ACHIEVEMENTS! <-- how many other games do you know that do this?

They have excellent sales on non-premium ships & stuff as well as packages/ premium stuff all the time. If you think the DLC is expensive & you still want it, just wait for it to go on sale, but really you could own everything premium in-game for a fraction of the cost of other free-to-play games (or just get premium standards from achievements, inviting friends, etc.).



So what is great about this game & why should you play it:

It has PvP matches of many types & plenty of action with matchmaking.

It has PvE matches that are really fun.

It has special events/ deals/ & free stuff all the time.

It has an Open-World too, with many diverse star systems & fun missions to do, or you can just stealthfully search for loot worth in-game money & components to build stuff with (these star systems" change month-to-month as different factors occur
date: like for example: alien invasions & systems being destroyed or over-run). Watch out for the other players though if your hauling a full load of loots back to the space station otherwise you might get nabbed
recommended:
hehe :)

It also has a "sector control" component (basically sections of space where your faction can battle for control & this then gives your faction bonuses).

It has a component kinda like Real Time Strategy where you can send your unused extra ships out on contract missions & you get ship parts & munitions if they are successful.

It has the fun 6 axis space flight system & you can just use a mouse & keyboard to play
hoursPlayed:
or use a joystick if you want.

It's only a 5GB Install (which is surprising considering the size of space depicted & what is all in this game).

You can play with friends/ with a large corporation/ or be a loner it really makes no difference.

They give out free premium credits (called Galactic Standards) & free stuff all the time & you get nice freebies every day just for logging in!

You are able to craft your own weapons/ munitions/ ships/ etc. (but you don't have to craft anything just to be successful).

You don't have to play everyday just to be competitive. Play it for a few hours & you can set it on the back burner & come back to playing later
voteText: or play everyday cause there's plenty to do. You won't be compelled by some outrageous subscription fees or feel that you're falling off by not playing like other space games.\n\nBeautiful graphics & space scenery & you can decorate your ships with skins & decals (my favorites are the pirate flag

votesHelpful: & the snooker (8-ball)).\n\nGreat audio & reactive in-game music that changes depending on what your doing (like when your in combat or enter a different star sector
votesTotal: or just chilling out floating around in space looking for some minerals
votesFunny: components

reviewText:
Recommended to anyone who likes space game though as all FTP games they want ur money, i personally see no problem spending 20-50 USD when the sales come up. After that its hard core grinding and moving along. :) Also highly recommended to join a Corporation since they will usually help u advance and lvl up. :) Ive been playing this game for a few years and enjoy playing it every time :)

For corporations to join if u like nice people, respect and NO DRAMA, I recommend checking out http://JungC.ORG

Other game info:
Game has dramaticly improved and is way better then it was a few years ago, though i hope they dont over do it now.

PVP aka Skermish
PVE aka VS AI
Sector conquest aka t4-t5 ships battle it out sectors for their faction and Corporations
Open Space aka some places pvp some places pvp and pve and some sectors can be captured by corporations

UPDATE 27th march 2016
Ok now we have pvp vs AI? and destroyers. Oh and it's definitely a PAY to WIN game. Sadly they over did it...

UPDATE: 24th May 2016
So the PVP vs AI thing (aka Co-Op) has its ups:
- Less wait time for matches.
- Can creat a wing (have 8 - 16ppls vs AI).
- The Destoyers... Very nice well done. Best in open space with good team mates (Finaly can take out Predator :).
- About the pay to win thing.... You can now get premium ships without paying real cash. yes its true, 3 of them to be exact and they are quit unique if i may add.
- Though with all this, yes you can have nearly everything in the game for FREE, if you spend about, lets say 4hrs a day, 5 days a week, for 2 years.
- Still very fun game love playing with the team. :)

reviewText:
Only recommend because I feel bad about not recommending a game that a lot of people enjoy. Not for me.

I dont feel developers should be allowed to accept money for in-game items that are subject to change at any point because the game is still technically in BETA. Figure out what you want to do then start charging. The game feels like its always wanting real money for something. Ammo, paint jobs, rolling on good items (with a very low chance of aquisition), ships, pilot license that expires and has to be renewed (gives XP boost that is almost necessary for any casual gamer). The list goes on.

No one wants to buy a Corvette on Monday just to walk out to a Pinto on Tuesday, because your dealership is in BETA. This is a horrible way to run a game.

PROS: Fast and smooth gameplay. Really is a good engine in my opinion. You dont HAVE to pay anything.
CONS: Money Pit - Forever in BETA - P2W (Worst parts of F2P - You FEEL like you need to pay to compete)

reviewText: Nope -- just nope. Gainjin seems halfway decent in War Thunder, making the grind not so bad.  This game on the other hand is a damned grind-fest. We play games to wind down after work, they shoudln't feel like a second freakin' job. Also, dunno if the admins are from gaijin (I wonder) or from Star Gem, but they... are bad.  I felt like the several interactions between players and the company's lackeys was very unprofessional and felt like the admins were 12 year olds on a power trip. They're also extremely absusive towards players, and dish out lots of trash-talk but can't take a professional sounding rebuttal.\n\nKind amakes me sad because the engine behind the game is really good, and there is a lot of potential there for them to have an excellent game, easily outclassing many others in the genre.  But the company's incessant demand for pay2win and abusive admin/GMs ruin the game.

reviewText:
I strongly recommend this game.
While it is indeed, as they say, *grindy*, it is very fun to play.
My hope is that they will decrease the grind later on overall, but if you focus on maxing out
the synergy of T1/2 you'll have a faster time synergizing the ship types you like to use in T3+.
I suggest finding a good class after you finish T2, and grind it straight to T5. You'll be able to get the ships
you want faster by using this method. Once in T5, you can even gain huge amounts of extra synergy.
Of course, currently, if you want to transfer extra synergy to other ships that you just don't want to grind, you can simply pay a small fee to transfer the synergy from your T5 ship to your T3+ ships when you wish to skip a few ships to the one you like.
Again, I really enjoy this game and will start playing it again as soon as I gain a computer that won't fry on me like the last one. :D

That is all

- WolfKhan

reviewText:
Game is grindy, but it has a great potential and awsome fights. Best I've seen. I'd describe it as Team-Fortress Classic in space.

Starting out all you want to do is get in fights and get kills, but that proves to not be the point. When you join with some better players you see that the ship's role (much like in team fortress) plays a major part in what you shold be doing.

Since the devs do look for money and use a pay-to-advance-faster system it is a bit frustrating to see people move forward if they pay money, but the game is free to play and with the price that it's worth (in my opinion in the few tens of dollars) you can advance to a top T1 **easily**. When you're a top T1 you can play T1 and no one has an advance over you other than implants.

Open space is nice but you really need a corporation (clan) for that, as well as dreadnaughts. You can use scanners to mine resources and advance a lot faster than you would otherwise. The community discovery is BAD and this is what really kills the game since you don't get a feeling of multiplayer when playing (no chat, no one uses voice in-game, no forums...).

All in all the game has great potential, very very fun and addictive, needs more players.

It is a free online game that is fun to play with friends. Its a Dogfighting space sim that runs smoothly and has simple controls.
Before buying a DLC, I advise you to play the free game first, as the DLC only gives you some extra equipment and ships. After a while I find the game to get a bit repetative.



I give it 8/10 as it did keep me entertained for 200+ hours and I still like to come back to it from time to time.
Its one of the best free games I ever played.

reviewText:
Two hours in and I can't see any Pay2win. There are people who are piloting better ships for sure, but even with the starter ship I was still getting a few kills on more expirienced players.

Not to mention this game has PvE for people who don't like the PvP and want to play a bit more casual, and a free roam mode (Albiet with limited fuel (that you can just refill by visiting another station)).

I'm having fun with it so far, it's a good F2P space shooter and we all know those don't grow on trees. Even though most of the reviews say neigh, I encourage people to at least download it and play for a while, you've got nothing to lose!

reviewText:
tl;dr Unashamed cash grab. SC abuses you for not paying(the most expensive and extreme I've encountered). Player base too small = queues are long, matchmaking doesn't work, no gear and fully geared players always in same matches.  Learning curve is ♥♥♥ backwards. Older players ignore objectives to stat farm new players. New Players don't know how to play objectives. Objectives are mostly ignored by all. PAY MONEY!

My stats for the game dont look great but that's all the time I spent helping/training new players. Made video tutorials and dedicated the vast majority of my time to helping new players get into the game.I thought that I'd help the game find its feet but the developers lied to us about what they were developing; it's not a game, it's punish-you-for-not-paying software.

Pre-release the interface was not litered with Buy this or that". The very first thing I noticed on release day was that the interface was suddenly filled to the brim with "Give Us Money" buttons
date: I mean filled to the brim: every weapon or item has the Premium stamp on it in one way or another. You can't ignore it
recommended: every menu or button you click will shout at you to pay money.\n\nI ♥♥♥♥in' wished I could install adblock in Star Conflict because the money whoring was so explicit that it became tiresome. If you don't pay you're not gonna have a good time m'kay. And ♥♥♥♥'s expensive yo. All progress is incrememntal and every step of the way features some way for you to pay. I mean hell
hoursPlayed:
I would have paid NOT to see all the ♥♥♥♥ing money whoring.

Progression:
Using phrases like learning- or skill curve is misleading as the game is designed in such a way that NEW PLAYERS WILL HAVE THE MAXIMUM DISADVANTAGE UNLESS THEY PAY. It's not pay to win
voteText: it's pay or get slaughtered like confused sheep over and over and over and over and over and over again. It's ♥♥♥ backwards because each time you level into a new Tier you have to grind to upgrade your weapons
helpfulPercent:
grind to upgrade your ships etc. This means that the only time you can compete on equal footing is when you have unlocked and maximally upgraded you ships/weapons/mods.

Queuing:
In the years I spent in this game a very very low percentage of new players stuck around. On release day they hid the PLAYERS ONLINE meter from the community. The queues are long and queuing in a group is painful and long and awkward and just kind of ♥♥♥♥♥ all round.

GRIND!
You HAVE TO GRIND for countless hours to get anywhere. Each time you move to a new level in the progression you have GRIND every ship and every weapon just to compete with guys who have fully pimped out ships.  The grind wears you down till you stop playing the game or spend money. In the meantime you will be abused by players with much more powerful stuff. The best you can hope for is to eventually become one of the abusers yourself.

The f2P claims for this game are BS. You get to "play" for free but you have to pay or die of old age before you will get anywhere.

reviewText: This game deserves more attention than it has gotten. The flight system is a modified version of the one used in Warthunder and expirienced players will have no trouble. It can take a few minutes to get used to flying with no down or up, but it can by fun to disorient players by coming at them along an odd attack angle. The game forces players to think in 3d, going under and over to flank instead of around, because there is no down in space. The crafting system works well and forces you to carefuly consider your play style. Best of all the dreaded Pay to Win" system is mor limited than most. Synergy transpher
recommended: and Premium ships are the only noticable advantages. reviewText:
I have been playing this game for over a year. I stopped for a bit while they worked out some beta issues, but I would reccomend this game for the folllowing reason:

If you love space combat, cool space environments, varied weaponry, and interesting space combat tactics I would reccomend this game as one of the best out there.  You can do quite well without ever spending a penny.

The 'freemium' element of this game is following a common trend with modern games, and at first I was really against it. Eventually I noticed there are major discounts now and then, and if you do purchase, it's basically convenience, and some unique ships that  are marginally better than others.  It's worth it if you think the game deserves your time, and a little investment to keep it running.


I say this game is great because it makes me feel like a space pilot from the tv shows I used to watch growing up. The combat is balanced enough that you can feel proud of yourself for beating an opponent, and I personally like the slow grind, because it gives me something to work towards.

In order to really like a game like this, you have to be unconcerned with the grinding, and enjoy the space dogfighting in a pure and well programmed way.  If you like to fight in space, then the grind is just a slow and steady stream of improvements on an already fun concept.



Pros:
Great gameplay
Cool graphics and environments
Many updates
Cool weapons
Many goals to work toward in game that yield rewards

Cons:
very slow grind
occasional rude players
long wait times for pvp and even pve on occasion.

reviewText:
Star Conflict [scon] is one of the best space based games I've ever played.
A real game immersion isn't really there (yet) but the individual battles are really something.
Corporations (Guilds) are the thing that keeps you entangled with scon.

It has some flaws, like weird/frustrating MatchMaking [MM] rules which change every now and then.

The grind without a premium license is hard and long. You should get a DLC (I recommend the Galaxy explorer pack when on sale and with the 10000 GalacticStandards [GS] you get a licence - also when on sale in game).
As casual player, only Tier 3 (of 5) has to be reached to play with most addons/mods active. Most players are in this Tier.
This game is NOT P2W, however the advantages of 'premiums' (real money bought, special ships) are numerous (which usually leads to the p2w argument) as in:
- they count as a rank lower than they actually are (so you trick the MM)
- they dont require repair (possibly saving loads of credits)
- they are fully synergized (levelled up) from the get go
- the Rank 9, Tier 3 DesertEagle has no standard equal (this is the one thing I'd actually agree on with the pw2 argument) Edit: this has been fixed with the introduction of the 'Achilles' gunship.
= included in the galaxy explorer pack ;)
- they allow ship reconstruction after defeat (ONCE per flight) in open world without using up a Duplicator
- they add 2 cargo slots to the base frame (e.g. interceptors: 3+2 slots)

Fast paced action, full 3D environment, a lot of different ships in 3 classes with 3 sub classes each.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game. I like to play it daily, but never for more than an hour or two.

Lets begin with the fact that it is free to play. In Star Conflict you pilot a space ship in approximately 10 minute matches. The matches include; Combat Recon: a deathmatch like game where two teams face off against each other and may respawn after death only as long as their captain is alive. Detonation: A capture the flag-like game where two team attempt to pick up a bomb and deliver it to enemy stations, winning when no enemy stations remain. Capture: Is a three point domination game where holding a base is worth points, so which ever team holds the most points over a duration will win. Domination: Is an elimination match, you when when you cap three enemy bases or you kill the enemy team. Hunt: Is a one moving point domination game where one of three points is active for 70 seconds during which the team who controls it earns points.


Players advance through a ranking system by earning credits (money) and synergy (xp). Players quickly gain access to three different hull types; Interceptors: Small-sized, lightly armed and shielded, agile, fast ships. Fighters: Medium-sized, heavily armed and lightly shielded ships. Frigates: Large-sized, heavily armed and shielded, slow ships. For the three hulls there are three sub-classes for every hull type. For Interceptors there are Covert Ops, Recon, ECM, each specializing in defeating a particular type of ship or performing a particular task. For Fighters there are Gunship, Tackler, Command. For Frigates there are Guard, Engineer, Long Range.

There are three factions, being a member of a particular faction will only determine who your opponents are. A player may purchase ships from any faction. Within each faction is a ship tree showing all the ships available and the path you must take to unlock them. Each faction will offer contracts that reward the player with special currencies that will allow for upgrades of specific weapons.

The game play is highly addictive. The controls are simple and intuitive. The game is enjoyable at every tier. Game servers handle latency very well. You wont get killed by the really laggy guy you never saw or not be able to hit the guy who skips all around.

For a free game that states it is a BETA, the devs keep you posted about updates and changes to the game and there are frequent updates.

My only complaint is that the player base is low, so the match making system can take 5 minutes to put you into a match during off-peak playing hours. During peak hours its usually under 30 seconds. In addition, the low player base forces the match maker to create matches that are slightly imbalanced ie everyone on the other team is more skilled than everyone on yours etc.

reviewText:
I'll start by saying I love this game. I set it aside from time to time but always end up coming back.

The graphics engine is beautiful, if you like sci fi ships this game has them in droves. A vast array of technological marvels to fly around and blow stuff up with.  The flight and shooting mechanics I find to be very tight and responsive. Sound effects are spot on, very satisfying and visceral.

The downside is the progression system is extremely grindy if you don't spend real money. Its not so bad if you are enjoying the gameplay, but sadly despite having several pvp and even pve modes, one can get burnt out because the gameplay itself doesn't vary much. Aim your reticle at enemies, fire until they explode, rinse and repeat. There are plenty of modules to give different abilities to your ship, hull and shield repairs, additional weapons or drones, disables, and while they do add variety I find myself wishing for a broader spectrum of tools to use to liven up the gameplay after a while.

I do still greatly enjoy it. Nothing around that I'm aware of that scratches the same spacey dogfighting itch while also being accessible, populated, and beautiful. But do be aware that while the game does not have a hard pay wall, it does make progress difficult past tier 2 without at least a small investment. I've spent money on this game, more than I'd like to admit. But I do it because the core game is fantastic, space battle goodness that deserves to be paid for.

reviewText:
A lobby based space shooter.

What's good.
1) Great space fighter with much more customization options than the rivals, through diverse module slot distribution and multiple types of weapons with interesting mechanics.
2) Almost perfect free to play model. The grind is not too much (though it's certainly there), and the ships you can buy with money are not strictly superior (though they are better in some ways, just like every ship has their own quirks).
3) Very nice gradual learning, you start with very few options, slower ships, only one game mode, and you ramp up the number of modules and modes you can use gradually through the tiers.
4) Developing competitive side. Observer system already in place, tournaments are held, teams are preparing well ahead.
5) Multiple game modes with their own interesting mechanics and multiple maps, some very imaginative.

What's bad
1) Low population, and all that comes with this. Sometimes long Q times for some modes.
2) No skill based matchmaking, so everyone is thrown into the game as equals (except squads who have to be matched by an enemy squad), which sometimes lead to very unbalanced matches.
3) The game is not really dynamic compared to shooters like Freelancer or even Moon Breakers, if you fly anything other than an interceptor than you usually strafe behind cover more than you dogfight, which is fine for frigates but a bit weird for a fighter.
4) Somewhat lacking balance, one shiptree (graph) (Jericho) is considered strictly inferior in most areas to the others. Hopefully will be patched, and anyone can play anything anyways, it's not restricted, players don't belong to a side.

All in all, a very enjoyable space shooter, even if somewhat grindy, but if you enjoy your game, you won't notice it at all.

Sincerely: [NASA]fasz

A couple of days ago I was told about StarConflict by my friend jonathanwasnthere, after I got used to the controls and gameplay, I really enjoyed the game. It seems like the main objective of the game is to get the next better ship you can get and by doing pvp and pve mission help you get closer to being able to do that. As a begginer, pvp isn't the best gamemode to go into when you just star because there are many other skilled players in better ships who will just blow you up multiple times. pve is alot better to do to get started because you work with others to get though a mission that doesn't involve fighting other people who are most likely more skilled than you, also pve mission normally give off better rewards than pvp.

I would definitley recommend this game to other people, it is very good quality for a free game (though there are aspects of the game that you would need to pay for if you want it) and I thing anyone could play this game and enjoy it. The only weakness I have found in this game is pvp miss-matches.

reviewText:
I personally think this game is awesome, I like flying spaceships, mainly the guards but dont mind playing the engineer from time to time.
Advantages of Star Conflict:
There are different types of roles you can play, such as Fighter, tackler, frigate-(Guard, Long Range and Engineer) and interceptor.
You can respawn as many times as you want.
Loads of different maps-(Inclueding SOME massive ones)
The amount of detail on ships, background's etc. are awesome
Different types of weapons/Modules
Different types of modes-(Beacon Hunt, combat Reacon ETC.)

Disadvantages of StarConflict:
I really find annoying the amount of time you have to wait, to get into a battle. E.G: 3-5mins to get in one battle-(Somtimes less).
Grinding takes a long time-(but in a way it is good cause you cant rush through the game like in a day or so)
The battle's dont last that long. Cant remember the correct time of the battles but no more than 10minutes, cause when you are flying a frigate and they are slow, and you get a massive map, it will take you ages to get from the spawn point to the area you want to get to.
Factions are to upgrade your weapons/modules from MK-3 to MK-4 but it used to be free when you changed contracts but now they changed it where you now have to pay credits-(In game money) or gold. Changing contracts means changing hangers but different weapons/modules use different contracts. BUT one good thing is that you keep the loyalty vouchers when changing. Cost to change faction from 200.000 to 750.000.

Overall this game is GREAT and I will recommend StarConflict to people who love flying spaceships.
I will give StarConflict 8/10. I am giving them this score because they changed the factions. If they did not mess around with that I would of gave them 10/10

There are different types of roles you can play, such as Fighter, tackler, frigate-(Guard, Long Range and Engineer) and interceptor.

Cost to change faction from 200.000 to 750.000.

Overall this game is GREAT and I will recommend StarConflict to people who love flying spaceships.

reviewText: While this game is free to play, it is certainly NOT pay to win. I have roughly seven hours logged, and I'm able to dominate pvp matches. This game is about nothing more than skill. Even if you encounter somebody with a better ship than you, if you play smart you can will beat them. There is also an open world, or universe I guess, feauture where you can fly around visiting other stations and locations. The only downside to this game that I have found so far is the long wait times for finding a game. Sometime you will wait as many as four to five minutes to find a lobby for a seven minute battle.\n\ntl;dr: 9.2/10 Would reccomend.

reviewText:
A couple of days ago I was told about StarConflict by my friend jonathanwasnthere, after I got used to the controls and gameplay, I really enjoyed the game. It seems like the main objective of the game is to get the next better ship you can get and by doing pvp and pve mission help you get closer to being able to do that. As a begginer, pvp isn't the best gamemode to go into when you just star because there are many other skilled players in better ships who will just blow you up multiple times. pve is alot better to do to get started because you work with others to get though a mission that doesn't involve fighting other people who are most likely more skilled than you, also pve mission normally give off better rewards than pvp.

I would definitley recommend this game to other people, it is very good quality for a free game (though there are aspects of the game that you would need to pay for if you want it) and I thing anyone could play this game and enjoy it. The only weakness I have found in this game is pvp miss-matches.

Rating: 8.5/10

reviewText:
I have heard quite a bit of negativity regarding this game but I downloaded as I heard about the native Oculus Rift Suport. I really like the look of this game though some of the options are a bit confusing and I could not find native support for my flight stick (SPEEDLINK BLACK WIDOW.) so manual configuring and working out the options did take some time. I also could not locate the first person view option on ly a third view perspective after scouring the menu options as well as looking at key bind options

I think that this is really good considering you can play for free. I heard that the moderators are strict so I will not be getting into disputes to find out if this is true or not.

Made by the same team as WARTHUNDER so if you enjoy that then you should give it a try.

First Impression verdict.

If you own an Oculus Rift then yeah you should definatly check it out but if you own ELITE DANGEROUS then there is no real reason to stay too long. I would love to see the game grow and be able to compete with its WW2 counterpart

reviewText:
Like World of Tanks in space
+ Many ships
+ Free (with free i mean if you meet player with premium equip, it doesnt make him immortal - 50% of game is strategy and choice of ship - different enemy needs different strategy)
+ Different ship classes alowing different combat styles (sniping,hunting with fighters,tanking with frigate
+ achievements allowing you to get few premium coins
+ premium currency obtainable for free during events (not very often, but still)
+ Fast missions (5-10 mins per PvP fight)
+ Ugrading equip,customizing ship,skilltree
+ PvP and PvE. In PvE you can participate in story in open space
- AI (bots) are pretty useless in game (buggy,easy to kills,predictable). Even in PvP half of each team are bots.
- Not many different maps
- Boring quests in open world like searching for target for 10 minutes
- grinding, grinding, grinding - stereotype comes really fast
- no wiki or turtorial that will explain you later parts of games

reviewText:
If you grew up playing old dos games like Descent, chances are you will love this game.  Honestly I haven't played many games like this since I shy away from shooting games.  I grew up playing the old FPS games like Doom, Quake, Unreal Tournament.

On to the pros:
The pvp in the game is very fun.  Lots of pvp game types.  Over 200 ships.  Progression is very fun.  Basically you unlock more ships the more you level up the ones you have.    6 degrees of freedom.  Tons of ship modules/weapon types.

Cons:
Pve is fun at first but then feels repetitive.  Open world so far seems fairly limiting.  Basically pickup fetch/kill quests.  I don't mind it but maybe if they had an event system it might feel more dyanmic and alive.  Maybe the higher level zones have a more organic feel.

reviewText:
What makes this game unique also makes it hard to master, the game is free 2 play, but as with most games, if you like it and find it fun, you can enhance the amount of xp and credits earned by paying for a monthly license. The game has several playstyles where if you want fastphased combat, an interceptor provides that, a frigate is slow but can take a beating, or lightly armored but does a lot of damage. You also have fighters that are a mix of both.

You get to explore the open world in a freelancer-like fasion, where you can run into pirates or aliens.

The game is fun, however the first few rounds in pvp where you have to learn the game can be a challange.

If you join and want to play with others hit me up at ingame name: storwin

reviewText:
Great game for those who love Space games, those out there who really like Sci-Fi! However, if you like EVE online, this is NOTHING like EVE, for this is more a TPS then a space tactics game. In this game you will have a lot of fun blowing up and blowing the others up. In the lower tier, like Tier 1 and 2 ships, you can have a lot of fun, however, as you advance in Tiers, it gets much harder to kill and be killed, so watch out for that.

A final thought, if you are not russian, and will play the game with 100-300ms of latency, it can be a little annoying getting killed by russians with 10-20ms latency, since the Shooting and Moving of the ships are all influenced by LAG.

That's all, hope you like my review.

reviewText:
1.250 hours on the clock. What more is to say?

++++++++++++++++++++++++++ Update on April 2nd; 2015:
Maybe it is time to add something in response to some other so called reviews around here:
There seem to be some players, who are talking about abusive admins etc. Since more than 1250 hours active game time I have seen not a single use of admin powers in terms of banning, let alone abuse.
If you carefully read through those comments, they later all have to admit, that they were swearing, talking about drugs, using political names etc. For that, they got warnings and chat-mutes of a few hours.
And now, we have some bad mooded kiddies who seek their revenge in negative comments.

I suggest: if you ARE interested in this kind of game, try it for free. If you later decide to spend money on a DLC or Premium, you can do so by a personal opinion. Until then, you can enjoy the game for free.
++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Well, apperantly a lot. First - like a lot of those games (War Thunder etc.) you need to invest some hours to learn the game mechanics and what ship is doing what. Second, you need some patience, as this game is more or less in constant development. Sometimes they make it better, sometimes they make it worse.

But, after all, it is free, and it generates a lot of fun. Especially, if you do it with a buddy or join one of the (better) corps (like clans) to play this together. There is PvP, PvE and an Open World Mode called Invasion (involves some Aliens).

There are Premium ships, but they have not more killing potential than other, normal ships - they just don't need repairs and generates some % more free synergy (to level your other ships).
Hint: don't spend your real money for transferring this synergy, but if you want, invest it in a licence to get more loot. If you have any questions, feel free to ask or go to the official forum pages @ forum.star-conflict.com

reviewText:
space ship!Obviously this game isn't for everyone it has a small target audience, but if you are like me and love your sci-fi and really want to fly then you might like this game.
It's a space flight sim at its core but it isn't super complex with every button on the keyboard doing something like the old X-wing and Tiefighter games.
The game sports heaps of different types of ships and classes ranging from heavy engineering frigates to fast interceptors meaning that there is a ship in the game will probably be to your liking.
As you progress through the levels you start getting access to more weapons and moduals and each level and tier you go up sees you looking through your new ships equipment slots seeing what new toys you can put on your ship. And this really does make it feel like the ship is your own.
overall if you enjoy your sci fi and your fying games like Hawx I would suggest you give this game a go and if you like it well then enjoy.

reviewText:
Imagine a generic multiplayer first person shooter.
Imagine it has a game mode where one player in each of the two teams is the leader" or "king" that has to be defended by the others while hunting the other team's leader.
Now imagine that with spaceships in small and confusing levels.

Still with me? That's all Star Conflict appears to be.
I can't say I've stuck with it for a long time
date: since I was expecting it to have anything other than this one hyper-specialized single thing (maybe some exploration? a campaign mode? challenges? anything at all?!).\nIf you like the sound of this then give it a shot
recommended: but don't be like me and install it with the wrong expectations."

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game highly enough. Sure, there's a high skill curve involved, but the community is very helpful in getting you started in your pilot career. Just ask questions, and you'll get all the answers you need. Find what you like flying best, and improve at that before branching out into other ship classes.

As for GMs abusing their powers like in the negative reviews, I have personally never seen that. In the 700+ hours I have played this game. The GMs I know are very nice and very polite, and they do not hesitate to play with people and help out in any way they can!

The game could use a few tweaks, but the devs do listen to our suggestions and are constantly improving and balancing the game. We have a very active forum that is constantly suggesting what can be done to our game.

Get this game, grab your friends, form a squad, and prepare to shoot. A lot.

reviewText:
It is not eve online or star citizen, but it sure as hell comes damn well close.

I heard it's from the same publishers as War Thunder and honestly I don't really care. This was a well made game through and through. Flight controls are slick and sharp. The extreme detail that goes into the modeling of the ships is astounding. And your guns even swivel when you move your cursor. They SWIVEL to aim where you are aiming at. Dat SWIVEL.

And profesionalism aside, the grinding in this game is acceptable to say the least. Almost four hours into the game and I'm comfortable enough to handle a one on one dogfight with another player. Though I can see myself burning out after my fifth hour after i get the T5. Every ship that I unlock feels the same as the one before, only a tad bit stronger.

I will still recommend the game though for people who wish for a free to play version of star citzens dogfight mode.

reviewText:
This is a surprisingly fair F2P game.  I personally have a lot of fun with it (even when I get my teeth kicked in during a PvP Domination match).  I'll try to break it down, Pros and Cons.

Cons:
-Upgrades can be bought through GS (Galatic Standards, the in-game currency bought with actual money).
-Some ships can only be bought with GS.
-No safety net with items (currently).  If you accidentally sell something you didn't mean to, you're out of luck.
-Matchmaking doesn't seem to have a balance to it (yet).
-Open Space (the Eve/Star Trek: Online-style connected sectors map) is unforgiving.  When Cybers and Biomorphs start showing up, and if you're a new player, you're screwed.

Pros:
-Galactic Standards can be earned.  It's small, but you get 10 or so for every one or two victories in PvP.  That's a pretty fair shake, considering it's bought with real-world cash.
-GS can only be used to upgrade ships by converting Synergy (experience) from an elite ship (max level) into Free Synergy, which is also earned during matches.
-Dogfights are fun!  Seriously, there's nothing quite like circling one another in three dimensions, each trying to get behind the other while taking shots or firing missles.  It can be nerve-wracking if you're hull is damaged or your shields are out, and there's a certain thrill to pulling an enemy off one of your teammates mid-fight.  Or, you can sit back in a Harpy, or other long-ranged frigate and take pot shots with your Disintegrator.  Just watch those Command fighters, or Covert Ops.
-No ship is the strongest.  Each ship has a role, each role has a purpose, every ship has its strength and weakness.  The combat is more based on skill with your ships than anything.  Upgrades help to increase hull strength and shield capacity, or cooldown time on modules and weapons damage, and later variants of ships in the same role will often have better stats, but no class is omnipotent and even lower-ranked ships can be threats with skill.
-The grind for Credits (the techniqually buyable in-game currency, as GS can be exchanged for Credits with an admittedly good rate) is miniscule.  Just a few games and you're raking in hundreds of thousands of Credits for new ships, MK II weapon and module upgrades, and other things.
-You don't have to sell ships.  In fact, you can eventually get every ship, all maxed in level with MK IV modules.  You start with three ship slots (these are the ships you can choose during matches or for Open space), and can unlock a fourth with either level or Galactic Standards.
-The devs are very active.

On a more personal note, the game seems best enjoyed with a friend.  You don't even have to be a super serious player.  It's easy to pick up and put down.  If you have an interest in space dogfights and don't mind luck-based grind for upgrade materials or MILD pay-advantage systems, I would definitely recommend you grab a friend (or a few) and try it out.

Until next time, Mercenarcies.

reviewText:
Its fun pretty graphics, Lazers going pew pew pew and stuff. Sort of like War Thunder but with a space theme. If War Thunder and Fractured Space had a baby it would be this. Read on if you want some quick basic info about it that i think its all the main stuff.

The Good:

Its just really enjoyable to play for a free to play its great, not sure about the pay 2 win as of yet because i've only had 3 games. But so far it doesn't feel unfair i've not even leveld up yet.

Controls are simple but may be a bit odd to some The controls are similar to Strike Vector. Its a bit weird for the first minute or so but it works really well.

Dog fighting in this is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. The Rush having to go invisible to find a safer place to recover while your shields low. Its just awesome especially with an extra wide set up whether 21:9 or eyefinity custom res side by side on two or three monitors.

I can actually play this game in eyefinity mode across two monitors without the bezel in the middle annoying the ♥♥♥♥ out of me.

Manufactoring seems kinda cool you learn things, then process things and use things and i think you can sell them too for extra cash thingies in the game. What ever the blue stuff is.

Even your moms laptop should run this alright i get great fps with the settings turned up and my pc is running a R9 270x 2gb which is like a £120 gpu. (well more for mine because its an asus directcu ii top so that was 180 with bf4 a game i dont play).

The Bad:

Main Menu is a cluster ♥♥♥♥ full of all sorts of stuff you can't be arsed reading and looking into. But having said that the manufacture thing seems to make sense so far i've only done one item so far.

The time it takes to connect to a game. Over 5mins to join the same game with the same people. what the ♥♥♥♥ is up with that?

Some of the stuff doesn't make sense or it does but i'm just not figuring it out properly. I dont get the crew system thing for example. For some it will be a jump in and you'll understand it all for others it may be a wtf does that mean?

Other stuff:

People are ♥♥♥♥♥ing about abusive admins here in the comment section. Personally I have no idea i've had like 3 games with the same people in a row. Takes like 5mins to connect but it might be the time of day that i'm playing or maybe people don't play it anymore.  I dont know if it is few dedicated servers or what.

All in all Definately Worth a try. Its Free it wont hurt to have a different experience, you'll either like it, dislike it or hate it i'm just simply stating my thoughts about it. Its fun its gripping at times flying through asteroid fields during a team match that involves dying less than the other team due to reinforcement waves. The Domination matches. It  Looks awesome and is even more awesome when the action gets really intense. Also it doesn't require an amazing computer to run this. This much fun this nice pretty graphics and its free. What more can you want? There is a few irritating things like trying to time your cool down timers correctly for using flares or you wanna jump in a game quickly and your stuck connecting for 5+mins and then to find out oh hey the games almost over so you have to go through all that again. It does need more servers. But for what you get the game is pretty solid does a good job is fun pretty and easy to get the hang of.

give it an 8/10

I feel like it would be a 9 if it was a more simplified cleared up main menu page and the game had a proper ingame voice over tutorial to explain to you what the stuff on the menu is and how you get it. I personally don't like clustered menus. It gets a bit confusing and servers are a pain in the ♥♥♥.  The wait times are terrible and that is a huge deal breaker as it can lead to less time actually playing the game. I feel like it doesn't quite do enough to make the 10 it could do with more ships, more cosmetics and stuff for free to play users. Like pimping out the ships a bit with maybe neons or something would be cool just to give it that me more personalization (if thats even a word).

Just play it. Do the tutorial to figure the controls then just jump straight in a battle you'll see how much fun it is. Its not like you can do much after only doing a tutorial mission

P.S It needs more servers with more players on them! Sick of 4 actual players in the one game in total and the rest being ai bots. Get it fixed! It deserves it.

reviewText:
Pure PVP spaceship dogfighting goodness.
This is a game for the dedicated PVPer.

Star Conflict almost directly takes the model of World of Tanks, with tiered ship progression and team deathmatch style gameplay and builds upon it magnificently.

Unlike so many free-to-play games, Star Conflict bends over backwards to avoid pay-to-win issues. You can buy premium ships, but they simply fill slightly different battlefield roles or suit different builds. The meta is constantly evolving as pilots discover new builds and develop new tactics. Daily inter-corporation battles and weekly tournaments ensure that there is plenty of opportunity to sharpen your teeth.

The learning curve is steep at times, but perseverance is rewarded!

It takes real skill to excel in battle across 3 dimensions. It takes dedication to understand the finer points of equipment configuration.

Oh, and it's visually beautiful. I haven't hopped in a tank since I installed Star Conflict.

reviewText:
There are a lot of people who dislike this game. Before you believe what they say, go and look at how long they have played.  If it is less than 100 hours, I guarantee they are still learning how this game works. I have TONS of time invested in this game, and I can honestly say this is the best game I have ever played.  Why?  Well, it's free for starters, and that's a huge plus.

Many free games favor premium players—the ones who actually pay for in-game content—so that the incentive becomes to pay for content to gain the upper-hand.  While there is premium content in this game, it is not at all overpowered.  In fact, there are many veteran players like myself who choose regular ships over premium ships because we know the real difference between them and can make the right decision.  The truth is, while there are plenty of people who Pay to Win in this game, they do not win because of their money.  They win because of their time spent learning this complex game and growing from each battle—every win, every defeat.

There is plenty wrong with this game, however, but I see it more as a challenge than a hinderance.  First, the developers are Russian, so it is difficult to be in contact with them.  This might seem minor, but it has grown to become one of the biggest issues in the community.  However, much of the community is active on the forums, so we do have some contact, but mostly with moderators and game masters.  Secondly, the game is hardly advertised.  Obviously, this is a problem.  But the BIGGEST problem in the game is the lack of players, which kind of comes from the aforementioned issues.  I do not believe this issue will last, however; many are coming to the game because it is exciting, and it is growing...albeit slowly.

I really do love this game; it's a wondrous space-fighter with plenty of action and ships to choose from.  The grind in this game is very long, but it's worth it.  To be honest, it has to be this long because of how complex it is.  Too many people simply buy their way into T5 (the highest rank) and end up really bad.  Why?  Because they did not play their way to the top like most others.  This might be the longest way, and it might well be the most annoying way, but it is by far the best way to become good at this game.

So, if you are on the fence about whether or not to try this game, please, trust me—it is definitely worth a try.  What have you got to lose besides time?  It's well worth the time if you enjoy blowing things up, that's for sure.  Also, if you love space fighters, this is a game to check out and keep at it.

Do not give up in the beginning.  It is hard.  It is REALLY hard, especially when all the ships in T1 (the lowest rank) are all terrible.  When you get into T3 (basically the mid-game), you will see the game's beauty.  The epic fights, the ferocious clashes, the immense strategy.

Play this game, you will not regret it unless you give up.

reviewText:
This game is a ton of fun. It may not be for everyone, but I like it.

I will admit that this game is a bit tough to get through the bot filled tier 1 phase, and then the early under equipped phases when you finally make it to a new tier. However, with some planning on what to buy and when, this can be mitigated somewhat. I think it does a really good job of converting some of the familiar traditional flight combat sim mechanics into a more twitch based space theme. It forgoes a good bit of realism, but allows for more interesting matchmaking game modes, and an arcadey shooter feel.

I definitely suggest checking it out, especially since it requires no real investment to get started and look around.

reviewText:
For starters this game is still in its beta stage (I believe) however they are making great improvements every month. The combat is extremely well thought out and functions just right for a game that's all about avoiding aponents and shoting them down wile keeping yourself alive. On high end PC's this game preforms flawlessly, but on lower end PC's you may get a lot of lag or very low res textures, but the game should still be playable.

Soon enough open world exploarion wil be released out of its closed beta stage, and I believe that is when this game will really take off.

Should you be considering this game, you should know that the leveling and equipment selections are somewhat ok. Those who pay will have a clear advantage over those who don't, but its not as though its impossible to do well without paying, it just requires a heaping load more of skill to succeed.

I would seggest getting your friends involved too and communicating thourgh voice chat through steam. Being able to verbally communicate like you're the cast of some star fighting movie-spaceship-enterprise makes the combat and strategy tactics much better.

reviewText:
I have played this game before on a different steam account. So, I decided to play it again. There are a few points I would like to address.

1). If you played Warthunder and enjoyed it, and you also like Sci-Fi games, this is for you. It was made by the same developers that made Warthunder, World of Tanks etc.

2). This game features, PvP, PvE and Free roaming in the galaxy. Now, I have not explored the galaxy, I just went around for like 5-10 minutes, so I cannot tell you how big it is or what exactly you can do in it. You will have to go explore it.

3). PvP is like Warthunder, but with spaceships, PvE is a co-operative mission with 3 other pilots, it's like Warframe, but with spaceships.

4). The graphics of this game are pretty good. I have my settings all on the highest possibly, with the highest AA, everything turned on, and I am getting a solid 60fps no matter what is going on. I am running a GTX 660 oc and an i7-3770.

5). The controls are hard to get used to, and because it is 0 gravity, the space ship will behave eratically if you do sudden movements and turn suddenly, it makes me dizzy sometimes. So if you are the one that gets sick easily, stay away.

All in all, I would rate this game 8/10.

reviewText:
It is not eve online or star citizen, but it sure as hell comes damn well close.

I heard it's from the same publishers as War Thunder and honestly I don't really care. This was a well made game through and through. Flight controls are slick and sharp. The extreme detail that goes into the modeling of the ships is astounding. And your guns even swivel when you move your cursor. They SWIVEL to aim where you are aiming at. Dat SWIVEL.

And profesionalism aside, the grinding in this game is acceptable to say the least. Almost four hours into the game and I'm comfortable enough to handle a one on one dogfight with another player. Though I can see myself burning out after my fifth hour after i get the T5. Every ship that I unlock feels the same as the one before, only a tad bit stronger.

I will still recommend the game though for people who wish for a free to play version of star citzens dogfight mode.

reviewText:
This is a surprisingly fair F2P game.  I personally have a lot of fun with it (even when I get my teeth kicked in during a PvP Domination match).  I'll try to break it down, Pros and Cons.

Cons:
-Upgrades can be bought through GS (Galatic Standards, the in-game currency bought with actual money).
-Some ships can only be bought with GS.
-No safety net with items (currently).  If you accidentally sell something you didn't mean to, you're out of luck.
-Matchmaking doesn't seem to have a balance to it (yet).
-Open Space (the Eve/Star Trek: Online-style connected sectors map) is unforgiving.  When Cybers and Biomorphs start showing up, and if you're a new player, you're screwed.

Pros:
-Galactic Standards can be earned.  It's small, but you get 10 or so for every one or two victories in PvP.  That's a pretty fair shake, considering it's bought with real-world cash.
-GS can only be used to upgrade ships by converting Synergy (experience) from an elite ship (max level) into Free Synergy, which is also earned during matches.
-Dogfights are fun!  Seriously, there's nothing quite like circling one another in three dimensions, each trying to get behind the other while taking shots or firing missles.  It can be nerve-wracking if you're hull is damaged or your shields are out, and there's a certain thrill to pulling an enemy off one of your teammates mid-fight.  Or, you can sit back in a Harpy, or other long-ranged frigate and take pot shots with your Disintegrator.  Just watch those Command fighters, or Covert Ops.
-No ship is the strongest.  Each ship has a role, each role has a purpose, every ship has its strength and weakness.  The combat is more based on skill with your ships than anything.  Upgrades help to increase hull strength and shield capacity, or cooldown time on modules and weapons damage, and later variants of ships in the same role will often have better stats, but no class is omnipotent and even lower-ranked ships can be threats with skill.
-The grind for Credits (the techniqually buyable in-game currency, as GS can be exchanged for Credits with an admittedly good rate) is miniscule.  Just a few games and you're raking in hundreds of thousands of Credits for new ships, MK II weapon and module upgrades, and other things.
-You don't have to sell ships.  In fact, you can eventually get every ship, all maxed in level with MK IV modules.  You start with three ship slots (these are the ships you can choose during matches or for Open space), and can unlock a fourth with either level or Galactic Standards.
-The devs are very active.

On a more personal note, the game seems best enjoyed with a friend.  You don't even have to be a super serious player.  It's easy to pick up and put down.  If you have an interest in space dogfights and don't mind luck-based grind for upgrade materials or MILD pay-advantage systems, I would definitely recommend you grab a friend (or a few) and try it out.

Until next time, Mercenarcies.
