reviewText:
This game is a ton of fun. It may not be for everyone, but I like it.

I will admit that this game is a bit tough to get through the bot filled tier 1 phase, and then the early under equipped phases when you finally make it to a new tier. However, with some planning on what to buy and when, this can be mitigated somewhat. I think it does a really good job of converting some of the familiar traditional flight combat sim mechanics into a more twitch based space theme. It forgoes a good bit of realism, but allows for more interesting matchmaking game modes, and an arcadey shooter feel.

I definitely suggest checking it out, especially since it requires no real investment to get started and look around.

reviewText:
It is not eve online or star citizen, but it sure as hell comes damn well close.

I will still recommend the game though for people who wish for a free to play version of star citzens dogfight mode.

reviewText:
This is a surprisingly fair F2P game.  I personally have a lot of fun with it (even when I get my teeth kicked in during a PvP Domination match).  I'll try to break it down, Pros and Cons.

Cons:
-Upgrades can be bought through GS (Galatic Standards, the in-game currency bought with actual money).
-Some ships can only be bought with GS.
-No safety net with items (currently).  If you accidentally sell something you didn't mean to, you're out of luck.
-Matchmaking doesn't seem to have a balance to it (yet).
-Open Space (the Eve/Star Trek: Online-style connected sectors map) is unforgiving.  When Cybers and Biomorphs start showing up, and if you're a new player, you're screwed.

Pros:
-Galactic Standards can be earned.  It's small, but you get 10 or so for every one or two victories in PvP.  That's a pretty fair shake, considering it's bought with real-world cash.
-GS can only be used to upgrade ships by converting Synergy (experience) from an elite ship (max level) into Free Synergy, which is also earned during matches.
-Dogfights are fun!  Seriously, there's nothing quite like circling one another in three dimensions, each trying to get behind the other while taking shots or firing missles.  It can be nerve-wracking if you're hull is damaged or your shields are out, and there's a certain thrill to pulling an enemy off one of your teammates mid-fight.  Or, you can sit back in a Harpy, or other long-ranged frigate and take pot shots with your Disintegrator.  Just watch those Command fighters, or Covert Ops.
-No ship is the strongest.  Each ship has a role, each role has a purpose, every ship has its strength and weakness.  The combat is more based on skill with your ships than anything.  Upgrades help to increase hull strength and shield capacity, or cooldown time on modules and weapons damage, and later variants of ships in the same role will often have better stats, but no class is omnipotent and even lower-ranked ships can be threats with skill.
-The grind for Credits (the techniqually buyable in-game currency, as GS can be exchanged for Credits with an admittedly good rate) is miniscule.  Just a few games and you're raking in hundreds of thousands of Credits for new ships, MK II weapon and module upgrades, and other things.
-You don't have to sell ships.  In fact, you can eventually get every ship, all maxed in level with MK IV modules.  You start with three ship slots (these are the ships you can choose during matches or for Open space), and can unlock a fourth with either level or Galactic Standards.
-The devs are very active.

On a more personal note, the game seems best enjoyed with a friend.  You don't even have to be a super serious player.  It's easy to pick up and put down.  If you have an interest in space dogfights and don't mind luck-based grind for upgrade materials or MILD pay-advantage systems, I would definitely recommend you grab a friend (or a few) and try it out.

Until next time, Mercenarcies.

reviewText:
Its fun pretty graphics, Lazers going pew pew pew and stuff. Sort of like War Thunder but with a space theme. If War Thunder and Fractured Space had a baby it would be this. Read on if you want some quick basic info about it that i think its all the main stuff.

The Good:

Its just really enjoyable to play for a free to play its great, not sure about the pay 2 win as of yet because i've only had 3 games. But so far it doesn't feel unfair i've not even leveld up yet.

Controls are simple but may be a bit odd to some The controls are similar to Strike Vector. Its a bit weird for the first minute or so but it works really well.

Dog fighting in this is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. The Rush having to go invisible to find a safer place to recover while your shields low. Its just awesome especially with an extra wide set up whether 21:9 or eyefinity custom res side by side on two or three monitors.

I can actually play this game in eyefinity mode across two monitors without the bezel in the middle annoying the ♥♥♥♥ out of me.

Manufactoring seems kinda cool you learn things, then process things and use things and i think you can sell them too for extra cash thingies in the game. What ever the blue stuff is.

Even your moms laptop should run this alright i get great fps with the settings turned up and my pc is running a R9 270x 2gb which is like a £120 gpu. (well more for mine because its an asus directcu ii top so that was 180 with bf4 a game i dont play).

The Bad:

Main Menu is a cluster ♥♥♥♥ full of all sorts of stuff you can't be arsed reading and looking into. But having said that the manufacture thing seems to make sense so far i've only done one item so far.

The time it takes to connect to a game. Over 5mins to join the same game with the same people. what the ♥♥♥♥ is up with that?

Some of the stuff doesn't make sense or it does but i'm just not figuring it out properly. I dont get the crew system thing for example. For some it will be a jump in and you'll understand it all for others it may be a wtf does that mean?

Other stuff:

People are ♥♥♥♥♥ing about abusive admins here in the comment section. Personally I have no idea i've had like 3 games with the same people in a row. Takes like 5mins to connect but it might be the time of day that i'm playing or maybe people don't play it anymore.  I dont know if it is few dedicated servers or what.

All in all Definately Worth a try. Its Free it wont hurt to have a different experience, you'll either like it, dislike it or hate it i'm just simply stating my thoughts about it. Its fun its gripping at times flying through asteroid fields during a team match that involves dying less than the other team due to reinforcement waves. The Domination matches. It  Looks awesome and is even more awesome when the action gets really intense. Also it doesn't require an amazing computer to run this. This much fun this nice pretty graphics and its free. What more can you want? There is a few irritating things like trying to time your cool down timers correctly for using flares or you wanna jump in a game quickly and your stuck connecting for 5+mins and then to find out oh hey the games almost over so you have to go through all that again. It does need more servers. But for what you get the game is pretty solid does a good job is fun pretty and easy to get the hang of.

give it an 8/10

I feel like it would be a 9 if it was a more simplified cleared up main menu page and the game had a proper ingame voice over tutorial to explain to you what the stuff on the menu is and how you get it. I personally don't like clustered menus. It gets a bit confusing and servers are a pain in the ♥♥♥.  The wait times are terrible and that is a huge deal breaker as it can lead to less time actually playing the game. I feel like it doesn't quite do enough to make the 10 it could do with more ships, more cosmetics and stuff for free to play users. Like pimping out the ships a bit with maybe neons or something would be cool just to give it that me more personalization (if thats even a word).

Just play it. Do the tutorial to figure the controls then just jump straight in a battle you'll see how much fun it is. Its not like you can do much after only doing a tutorial mission

P.S It needs more servers with more players on them! Sick of 4 actual players in the one game in total and the rest being ai bots. Get it fixed! It deserves it.

reviewText:
Pure PVP spaceship dogfighting goodness.
This is a game for the dedicated PVPer.

Star Conflict almost directly takes the model of World of Tanks, with tiered ship progression and team deathmatch style gameplay and builds upon it magnificently.

Unlike so many free-to-play games, Star Conflict bends over backwards to avoid pay-to-win issues. You can buy premium ships, but they simply fill slightly different battlefield roles or suit different builds. The meta is constantly evolving as pilots discover new builds and develop new tactics. Daily inter-corporation battles and weekly tournaments ensure that there is plenty of opportunity to sharpen your teeth.

The learning curve is steep at times, but perseverance is rewarded!

It takes real skill to excel in battle across 3 dimensions. It takes dedication to understand the finer points of equipment configuration.

Oh, and it's visually beautiful. I haven't hopped in a tank since I installed Star Conflict.

reviewText:
Pay to win game, grindy as hell for regular players.

All good looking ships are premium - real money only. You get often teamed up vs higher tier of ships that wreck you due to their gear advantage. If it wasn't F2P, it would be much better game. Game itself plays great, gameplay is very fast, fluid, graphics are nice for a space shooter.

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game highly enough. Sure, there's a high skill curve involved, but the community is very helpful in getting you started in your pilot career. Just ask questions, and you'll get all the answers you need. Find what you like flying best, and improve at that before branching out into other ship classes.

As for GMs abusing their powers like in the negative reviews, I have personally never seen that. In the 700+ hours I have played this game. The GMs I know are very nice and very polite, and they do not hesitate to play with people and help out in any way they can!

The game could use a few tweaks, but the devs do listen to our suggestions and are constantly improving and balancing the game. We have a very active forum that is constantly suggesting what can be done to our game.

Get this game, grab your friends, form a squad, and prepare to shoot. A lot.

reviewText:

recommended: but don't be like me and install it with the wrong expectations."

reviewText:
WAR THUNDER IN SPAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACE!!!

A year ago, that would've been a compliment.
Since then, I'm 95%  sure that Gaijin's entire development team was murdered by robots and replaced by a belligerent artificial intelligence that only cares about squeezing money from the playerbase while trying to make Gaijin's once-majestic games as anti-fun as possible. It also completely ignores any and all player requests and/or feedback.

Now Star Conflict is more like a crappy pay-2-win version of Dark Souls (in space). Ranks 1-6 are still ok, if you don't mind grinding through the crummy tier 1 & 2 starter ships, but past that? Get ready to die. A lot.
...Unless you invest a crazy amount of time/money building a destroyer.

BTW, Gaijin's idea of balance improvements" in the last patch was giving the new Rank 11 destroyers a black-hole gun that bypasses shields and rips apart smaller ships in seconds

reviewText:
Rewrote the review.

I only played this game for a few hours so these are just my impressions.

GFX is pretty nice but the UI is poorly done and often I can't see the point where my guns are firing at.

Sound is OK.

Gameplay is very twitch-based shooter type and you select a handful of different classes and then you queue for instances to upgrade your ship or get a new ship. The instances I found quite bland and repetitive and got bored quite fast. I prefer more tactical games rather than shooter and even the biggest ship class in this game was more like playing a shooter.

There is supposedly an open world in the game, or upcoming, but I could not play long enough to unluck it. Which means you cannot enter anything but instances for the first hours of game play.

Bored me so I quit.

reviewText: The Game is great - but i prefer to not spend any money ! Why ? Star conflict has a few unsolved bugs and the support is the worst support i've ever seen. I spent about 130,- EUR for DLCs and ingame credits. While playing the game i earned about 9 mil. credits and bought a blueprint to upgrade a weapon to MK5 level. After purchasing the blueprint, i cannot use it but the credits are gone :( This is my bad way started.... I used the ticket system of gaijin and reported my problem using screenshots. reviewText:
When I first got this game (i believe it was in the spring of 2015) it was great, if somewhat overwhelming. once you get used to it the combat is fluid and the graphics are pretty cool. However, at the time my PC was pretty crappy and couldnt run SC well, which impacted my performance - it's very hard to react in combat with massive stuttering. I took about 2 months to research some upgrades for my PC and gather the money for it.

Once I upgraded my PC I could run the game like a dream - but I couldnt do anything worthwhile! The ranked match system is awful because it only allows specific ranks at certain times - and there's a 12 hour wait in between rank blocks, and in that time nobody of that rank is in unranked PvP. This wouldnt be that bad if PvE lobbies consisted of more than a handful of brain dead quarter-wits who havent learned to fire their weapons yet.

I might try again in a few months, see if this is remedied. Until then Im steering clear of this

NOTE: If you like space shooters/RPGs look up Freelancer by digital Anvil. Its old (and not on steam) but its well crafted, highly moddable, and still has people regularly playing online (you will need a mod like FL Universe or Hamburg City to play online, only takes like 10 minutes to find and install)

reviewText: The only thing worse than how terrible this game is, is that EA/Bioware literally stole it and put it in Star Wars The Old Republic.  Seriously, who thought a 3d space combat game WITHOUT joystick/gamepad support and a flexible targeting reticle was a good idea?\n\nNotwithstanding the amount of in-game corruption by cheaters and bots, the tiered-matchmaking system is flawed, creating an abysmal experience for new players routinetely pitted against vets with maxed-out ships.  This is essentially a pay-to-win microtransation game, with horrible physics and a horrible community.  As much as I loathe Galactic Starfighter in SWTOR, I would reccomend that pile of garbage over this game upon which it is based.

reviewText:
WAR THUNDER IN SPAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACE!!!

A year ago, that would've been a compliment.
Since then, I'm 95%  sure that Gaijin's entire development team was murdered by robots and replaced by a belligerent artificial intelligence that only cares about squeezing money from the playerbase while trying to make Gaijin's once-majestic games as anti-fun as possible. It also completely ignores any and all player requests and/or feedback.

Now Star Conflict is more like a crappy pay-2-win version of Dark Souls (in space). Ranks 1-6 are still ok, if you don't mind grinding through the crummy tier 1 & 2 starter ships, but past that? Get ready to die. A lot.
...Unless you invest a crazy amount of time/money building a destroyer.

BTW, Gaijin's idea of balance improvements" in the last patch was giving the new Rank 11 destroyers a black-hole gun that bypasses shields and rips apart smaller ships in seconds
date: and giving T3 bots maxed-out T5 ships with red-quality mods and +50% to firepower

reviewText:
Yeah ok. So I only have about 13 hours in this game at the time of this review. Either way, its enough to give me a relitive idea about this game.

Pros:
+ Relitivly easy to pick up if you have played war thunder
+ Map design is top notch
+ Some maps contain easter eggs (A few maps have souyze capsules floating around. Also a possible reference to gailin being a russian company)
+ Combat is nicely paced, with a ship type for everyone
+ Each faction feels sort of unique, especially in terms of ship design
+ No ship feels pointless (So far for me)
+ PVE integration is rather impressive
+ Feels fun when in a balanced match
+ Huge amount of content means that gameplay itself is rarelly ever boring

Cons:
- Gameplay is tedious at times
- The grind at times can be painfull, especially the synergy grind
- Some weapons feel a little bit unbalanced, namely coil mortars
- PVE tends to suffer from a serious lack of corrdinated teams, in the one game type that demands corrdination.
- Match search times tend to be very slow.
- Small team sizes plus team balance based on ship tier means that PVP can end up being rather unbalanced


Summary: The second you get into a balanced match in game, there is no other game I would rather play. There is no such thing as an average match. There are only painful matches, and awsome matches. Unfortunatly, the second you get into a badly balanced match, all the fun seams to leave this game. Although there is this problem, open space is always open and suprisingly fun. The real danger to this game is the boredom of looking for matches. Still, the cross game bonus features do make it worth trying out to at least get something out of this game.

8/10 Overall

reviewText:
Looks great, runs great, has plenty of content to offer, but much of it (especially the open-world part) is locked behind a ridiculous grind/pay wall. After 250+ hours, I'm still very 50/50 about this game. The devs recently added a new ship class which basically makes the other 3 classes obsolete, and of course you need to grind a lot to even get your hands on any of these new ships. You can't simply buy them for cash, which is also a 50/50 thing. It's not P2W, but the grind is painful.

It would be great if the developers focused on adding new content like maps and game modes, instead of new ships. But there's still plenty of PvP, PvE co-op and open-world fun to be had here.

reviewText:
I find that this game is extremely fun to play. I'm a huge fan of the space combat in Star Wars Battlefront II and I enjoyed this game immensely. There are many cool looking ships and I find that visually the game looks great.

I find that there's not many problems with PvP (Player vs Player) except that it seems as though some ships are a bit overpowered or annoying to fight such as the sniper

In PvE (Players vs AI), it can be fun and challenging for new players at first but when you get higher tier ships, the difficulty increases. The only changes that I notice between difficulties is that the enemies have more health (don't know whether if they deal more damage). I hate it when a higher difficulty means simply giving the enemy more health and/or damage.

Although I said the game is fun, over time it starts to become more and more boring and dull. This game is not really pay to win but instead it is pay to not grind. I find that there is a lot of grinding if you want to get to the higher tier ships since you need enough credits and experience from the ships of previous tiers.

Overall I think the game is a lot of fun to play for a while but eventually it will get old. But hey, it's free, so why not pick it up?

Hope this helps

reviewText:
8/10

Awesome game. After buying so much during the steam sale, I ended up playing this for free instead...
You fly combat spaceships and shoot at other spaceships with lasers and missiles and try to outrun them around asteroids. How could it not be fun? The controls are quite good and pilot skill is very well reflected in combat. The free to play model doesn't really hurt gameplay - it's ridiculously expensive when you want to get perks, but if you don't, you're never at a real disadvantage in a battle. Besides, you get grouped with other players near the same rank so that your opponents are never out of your reach.
The problem I had with the game is that you can only play in team modes - team deathmatch, domination (capture and hold flags), bomb - usually around 10 vs 10. Sometimes you'll end up on a team that's too strong and win by an incredible margin, and often it'll be the opposite. Your individual performance can help your team but sometimes you can have the game of a lifetime and still badly lose because you got unbalanced teams. It can get really frustrating and is the reason I stopped playing.
Do try it!
voteText: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I just can't see why someone says that a game is outright bad after putting more than 2000 hours in it. Because negative reviews say that. So I'm balancing here.

I havent played this seriously since before you could exit the hangar but It is still the same and still fun. Yes it is a bit grindy if you are a competionist but if you want good, fast spaceship pvp I still haven't found better. It not Elite D, or EVE but its a lot more accessible. It is fun pvp with a lot of upgrade options and ship roles to try out.
Some pointer good and bad, you decide.:

- Bunch of PVP game modes
- Different PVP brackets based on ship tiers
- PvE for those who care
- Has a fair bit of Depth but still very easy to get into
- Freelancer style controls
- Nice balance on lower tiers (dont know about higher, but noone is forcing you to go there)
- Skill IS important
- Can pay for a ton of stuff but Its just faster progress mostly.
- Is fun

I could say more but if you want to do spaceship pvp with nice graphics and fast paced action this is well worth the nothing you have to pay for it. :P

ps.: I payed for a bunch of games a lot more money that I haven't had this much fun with.

reviewText: Before, I'd given this game a rather harsh review. It is true that the rather limited aiming capabilities for certain ships is annoying, but that's really just about it. Are you the sneaky type? Three kinds of covert classes of ships are available to you. Are you the defense bolster? There are defense modules for every ship, and two ships that focus around just that. Maybe you prefer to just take the fight to the enemy as soon as possible, or scope them down, or buff you allies. The game is amazing, and honestly, I'm surprised that it's still free. My options are always open, and I know that anyone with a taste for science fiction will most likely find that true for themselves as well.\n\nTo the fallen, pride.

reviewText: Star Conflict has come a very long way since it's dawn years ago. Many have come and many have left, yet I remain. What holds me loyal to the game is not just the fancy graphics or the cool customizable ships, but the fun, fast-paced gameplay and amazing PvE missions that you can go out on. You can go from defending allied territory to taking down a massive alien dreadnought with a team of your stronest friends. After that you can cool off by flying around in the open world and fighting other players or AI enemies. You can gather resources and craft powerful weapons and modifications for your ships, and when you obtain a high enough rank you can even craft your own custom ship that you can outfit however you like! I really adore games with serious customization, but I seriously love this game's ship models. Every single ship is a work of art and they only get better as you go. It takes a while to gain traction in this game, but once you do, it will be more rewarding than ever.\n\nPlease, please keep playing the game beyond the first week or so. After you get moving and start getting more powerful ships and weapons and modules the game world opens up in so many ways. The start just sucks a little. ^^

reviewText: A great game with a decent concept that's plagued by a horrible progression system that encourages you to trend towards microtransactions. Add in to the fact you have to spend real-world money just to part up with anymore than two people, and you have a recipe for your standard greedy microtransaction based game.\n\nthe gameplay itself is fairly solid, ship-to-ship combat is interesting and the game looks and plays great. Its just a shame that its burdened by such terrible design decisions. I would've gladly paid 50+ dollars for a game like this, but the constant need to spend reworld money (or spend an absurd amount of time grinding) keeps me from spending any sort of cash on games like this.

reviewText:
I really love this game. A great sci-fi action game, comparable to Freelancer, but with much more depth and tactical aspects. For me, it is definitely not pay-to-win - if you want to spend money, you can get into the game a bit easier and faster, but you still need to play through the same parts of the game as anyone else, in order to get to the top tier ships.

Also, I was surprised about the game modes. Not only mission-based PvE, but also PvP (where even as a total newb you can be usefull), guild (called corporations") based campaign and a open world style free-flying mode.

The real downside is that the publisher/developer does not do more commercial and advertising to open it up for a broader audience. If you love games like Freelancer (for the action) or Privateer (for the freedom of play style) you should definitely try it out. If you are looking for a space sim
date: more into the direction of EVE
recommended: you may be disappointed.\n\nSee you ingame!"

reviewText: EDIT: updated to reflect recent updates\n\nThis is a game where you fly spaceships and shoot at other spaceships. There's not much else to it. I wouldn't say this is a try F2P, but it's not much of a P2W. Especially when you get in higher ranked battles, the people who bought there way to the top are the first to go. This is a game of skill, not fancy weapons. The game itself gives you plenty of opportunities to level up quickly. The only issue I have to complain about is that the instructions in the missions do not reflect the recent updates, so you may end up spending a good amount of time on google if you wish to do the missions (which are completely optional, but they do have their rewards). In terms of combat it's pretty simple in terms of HUD readability and controls. Matchmaking is based on ship rank, so you will be fighting players of multiple different skill levels (which can be a good thing and a bad thing). If you really are that bad (when you are starting out), there are plenty of bot players that are added to both sides that give you a few free points and target practice. There is also a mode now where you can freely roam the sector (assuming you are ready to take on enemy pirates and players that may come your way). In terms of the ships, no matter what faction you choose, there are 3 basic ship classes. Recon: fast and deadly but almost no shields. Commander: good balance between weapons and shielding, moderately fast. And engineering ships: painfully slow, but extremely deadly to anything in front of it, plus high shields. So as you can see there is no master" ship. Despite what you may see above
date: in actual combat you will learn quickly that all ships are equal
recommended: it's just a matter of learning what your ship was built to do. Upgrade paths can be confusing. There is no "this is level 2
hoursPlayed: this is level 3". You can mix and match almost any weapon type (assuming there is a version of that weapon for your ship class
voteText: some weapon types are only built for a specific class). You can also upgrade your shield
helpfulPercent: engine
votesHelpful: targeting computer
votesTotal: and pretty much anything you can think of. You can also upgrade the entire ship using synergy. Synergy is accumulated at the end of battle (usually only when you win)
votesFunny: and can be used to level up all components of your ship.\n\nShort version of this review: It's addicting
commentsCount: it's fun. It's a nice break from other "shoot 'em up" games. And it's free. If you are really impacient

reviewText:
Product received for free

Had the game for a few days now and I'm really enjoying it. The ships play their roles well, the missions are interesting as you unlock them, the game looks great...

The amount of time it takes and how many times you have to repeat the same missions in the same starter ships to get out into open space almost turned me away. While I love PvP and PvE in the game, the ability to undock and poke around before you have 10 hours in would have helped a little.

The factions don't seem to really have much point other than design and the extent of universe to explore outside is kinda limited.

It would be nice to be able to take a more Galaxy On Fire approach to travel. Hopping around from station to station picking up work instead of always killing and collecting for the same people.

As far as a space shooter goes. It's good. It's fun. You can manufacture new massive ships, explore space for parts and work together with friends to get things done. It's nice to pull a small squadron together with a couple fighters and a support frigate.

Solid recommendation for a pretty solid game that won't eat your entire life away.

reviewText:
Average F2P-Space arcarde space shooter from Gajin.  Unfortunately, without any depth. The first hours you spend leveling your ships up are very easy and calm. After that, you get into bigger and more interesting fights with more players. Because of the F2P model and the pegi 12 rating this game also attracts lots of kids (The amount of autism in the chat is too damn high) and imbecils, players don't cap empty nodes (like flags in a CTF-game mode) because they don't even care about them or are busy doing whatever they are doing somewhere else which makes a dedicated player rage from time to time.
Already mentioned, the game is missing depth. You can upgrade your ships weapons and systems and get new ships through grinding. That's it. There are not even more than 1 main-weapon systems (rockets/torpedos, railguns/lasers) per ship that you can use, at least not from the ships I tested. It contains a PVE mode through that you also can level and grind your ship up which I find very good.
There are basically 3 different ship sizes. Big slow ones, medium ones and small agile ones.
My conclusion: Try it out, there's nothing world-changing in this game but it's not bad.
I decided not to play it over long terms because I find the stuff the game has offer to me simply boring.
The only difference in the higher tier ships and the lower tier ships is that the higher ones have more grinding levels" (called synergy). They basically look all the same and are the same size while using the same weapons. Why should I bother reaching those ships then?"

reviewText: Star Conflict is a MMO Flying Fighter. It is based in space as you are in a starfighter. There are ranges of ships to choose from which you can unlock and buy. I say this is a game for the MMO fans and Star Wars and Star Trek fans. It is a good flying fighter but I think I would rather something a bit more this age of time. But don't let me get in your way of your gaming. Star Conflict still is a great game, but I think it can be better. I do recommend this to players but be prepared for online chats on the side of your screens of other players. If you are thinking of this game for your child 8 or 9 or 10 and below I would recommend to superzise them at all during the game. And if they are that age, I wouldn't recommend steam for them either. But like I said, don't let me get in your way. Enjoy!

reviewText:
Do you like space battles? Do you like dogfights? Do like explosions and lasers? Do you like nonstop PVP action? Then you should definitely check this game out!

This is one of my favorite Free-to-Play games available on steam. The number of hours I have on record should be an indication of how much I love this game. There are over 100 ships to fly and obtain, a pretty good community, and lots of battles to participate in. There's an open space exploration, PVE co-op missions, and the new update includes a new mechanic; DREADNAUGHTS. If you're part of a corporation (clan) your corp can get a dreadnaught to participate in sector conquest.

Basic Stats Rating:
Graphics/Visuals- AWESOME
Gameplay- AWESOME
Notes on Gameplay/Mechanics:
-There are 3 main classes of ship (Interceptor, Fighter, and Frigate), and 3 roles for each class
-There are 15 ranks and 5 tiers of ships.
-Ships are customizable in durability, handling, abilities, and weapons. Color is customizable for gold standards (real money)
-There are 6 PVP game modes and a nice variety of PVE co-op missions. There is also the open space available as well where you can explore the different sectors of the system.
-There is  a ship-crafting/module crafting system, but that's really only available to higher-tier players. Each faction has 1 ship that can be crafted, and it can take a long time to get all the resources and parts to craft them.
Community- Pretty good
Pay-to-win? Not really, spending money will get you better ships faster, but in the end it all comes down to skill and teamwork
Plot: Not the reason you're playing, but there is a kind of lore/backstory
Should you play? YES!

Major" Con (what many people consider to be a con):
This game will get REALLY GRINDY if you don't want to spend a LOT of money on it (I
recommended: haven't spent a single penny yet). In order to unlock new ships
hoursPlayed: you have to earn "synergy" (exp) on the ships you own. Once you reach a certain synergy level
voteText: the next rank of ship(s) in that class will be unlocked for purchase. This will take time.\nHowever
helpfulPercent: when you are finally able to get a new ship
votesHelpful: you will feel like you've earned it. But if you enjoy the gameplay and don't really care about corporation politics and whatnot
votesTotal: then I wouldn't consider this too much of a con."

reviewText:
This game is AWESOME for those who love having to make decisions in a split second. The best part about it (to me) is how active the staff are when updating their things. They have synergy bonuses and double credits on lots of weekends! A LOT of people say this game is a Pay 2 Win, it isn't really, as long as you use the ship you have right you can wreck people who pay for their ships. And as a payer myself, I can tell you that people wreck me ALL THE TIME because I'm a fairly reckless player. With one of the squishest ships in the game (Tackler) I have to keep up with sheer skill, I outfitted my ships for a more 'agressive' part. Having lots of speed and capable of tanking hits that even Zealots fall to, it is a TON of fun to play. It is like World of Tanks or War Thunder, but in 3 DIMENSIONS with obstacles and asteriods to use to your advantage.

OVERALL:

FUN TO PLAY - 8
SKILL REQUIRED - 10
COMMUNITY - 8.5
SHIPS & GRAPHICAL DESIGN - 9
STAFF - 10

TOTAL: 45.5

reviewText:
It is fun in the beginning, but with reaching the second tier it feels like running into a brick wall.

From there it's either getting carried by other players through the mission, or getting turned into scrap metal within seconds of stage 2 or 3 of the current mission.
So, it is back into the lower tier, to get more money for better ships and equipment, and then perhaps give the higher tier a new try.

If you have no problem with grinding through lower tier missions to get better equipment and ships, that will stand a real chance in the next tier, and the fact that this game is focused on PvP, go ahead and wing it.

The F2P seems fair, and not really P2W, but i can't recommend this game at the moment. Perhaps if they adjust the difficulty, i might give the game another chance.

Visuals and sounds are ok.

Update:
The Age of Destroyers" pretty much destroyed the game itself. The missions are now "balanced" on destroyers
date: even when there are no players with destroyers in your group.\n\nMost events only feature max. synergy ships
recommended: and even if you have one
hoursPlayed: you have to fly several missions for a random reward... to sum it up
voteText: the game has been turnend into a massive luck based grind."

reviewText:
if your willing to dig deep into your pockets and eventually spend at least a couple hundro dollars. This game can be very satisfying. Beautiful free space sectors with various facets from treasure hunting, to very diverse questing, and even nice battles. Great PvP and PvE instances, and I mean great. But yes, you must pay lots of money!!! and you better know how to spend it because if your a noob, you could easily blow through $100.00 dollars truly believing your doing proper with it and  end up wasting every penny. I got lucky and cashed in on a 90% off ship sale, all ships. Without that I wouldn't be past tier 3 because the ships are about $40.00 each and to reach T5 you have to purchase some earlier ships. While this game is P2W, it is honestly kind of reversed. You pay first, to win later. The initial investment allows you to have a good base to earn synergy, credits and loyalty with bonuses from packs and the cash shop ships which generate extra synergy for faction ships.. Later down the road you build the ships in your faction trees, which are actually better ships. Wait, the progression ships are actually better than the $40.00 ones?  Yup, good luck getting them without the cash shop ones though. That said, there are a ton of good players in game that haven't spent a single dime and are probably the best players. (much grinding)
All that said, I really do recommend this game. Even if you dont pay a dime, you can have a lot of fun. If your willing to put some money into a game it's a good one, If your not willing to put money into this game though maybe stay away because you will like it so much you'll make poor life decisions and spend money on it anyway. Which is what I did $200.00 later.

Would spend $200.00 again and probably will.

reviewText: Definitely worth downloading. Similar to conquest mode in Battlefield except it's in space, only better/more features and gameplay. 8.5/10 now all they need to do is let you land on planets seamlessly in real time complete with re-entry fireball effects and have ♥♥♥♥♥♥meplay on the ground or a star fox style minigame, also walking around the ships would be a nice addon. But seriously, this is actually one of the best if not hands down the very best experience I have had on the Oculus DK2. It's also easy to join up with friends. The situational awareness in VR is really good, and it stays locked at 75fps hardly any lag and no judder. Very immersive, the combat is addictive. Some interesting loot and crafting materials can be salvaged and the game universe can be explored if you undock your ship from the station as opposed to entering the PVP skirmish matchmaking countdown. Not sure if it's an MMO, but it would be a really good MMO and the ship physics are fun. Very comfortable VRexperience.

reviewText:
On me: Over 2000 hours in game, 4500 matches, all ships played and maxed, build a corp from scratch to 150 members and top-10 PvP leaderboards, organized and played dreadnought matches. Considering myself a casual player - can take on almost anyone on a good day, or die like a newb on a bad one.

On the Game: Great, addictive game. Maybe the best space combat game currently on the market. Spaceships, fights, PvE & PvP, open space, pirates, aliens, missions, ship customization, great graphics, low requirements, linux & mac support - everything you want from a space combat game and much more. Also much more mature than most other space combat offerings on Steam, and far more dynamic and  interesting than e.g. Elite:Dangerous. Basically it's War Thunder in Space.

Try it, it's free, and up to the mid-tiers the grind is moderate (and mid-tiers are much more fun than high-tiers anyway). If you have the time and patience to improve your gameplay to competitive levels, this may be a game worthy of long-term engagement.

As reference: without investing any real cash, it will take you about 100-150 matches to maximize all Tier-1 ships. With licence etc. it will take 3000 to 5000 matches to maximize all ships in the game, if that is your goal.

However, you need the frustration tolerance of a tibetan monk after Tier-1:

- Matchmaking is super-broken and will put new players with 100 matches against unbeatable veterans with 10'000. Often. And in every Tier (except 1). Only thing worse than normal" matchmaking is squad matchmaking - the only balancing there is the amount of players in squads to be near-equal. The game doesn't even try to match based on skill or experience - I've seen squads with 300 matches total placed against squads with 30'000 matches total. Matchmaking generally feels worse than random - it seems the goal is to frustrate players on purpose
date: to get them to buy "better" stuff and spend more money on the game. Newer players complaining about the frustrating game experience are told to simply "gid gud"
recommended: as if every casual player had the intention to spend 2 years of his life in the game.\n\n- Tiers are supposed to be skill-related
hoursPlayed: but that is not the case. There are just as many new players in T5 as there are experienced veterans. Lower Tiers (T2/3) are chock-full of uber-leet veteran players and  - even worse - elite kill squads "seal-clubbing" / "farming" newer players for easy wins which yield stats and Iridium for the corp.\n\n- A lot of the vet no-lifers are extremely abrasive
voteText: insulting other players at every opportunity. The vets basically "own" the game (or at least act as if they did)
helpfulPercent: and vet squads and corps dominate the whole gaming experience. Newer players (anyone with less than maybe 3'000 matches) are treated as cannon fodder. This
votesHelpful: together with the disgusting matchmaking
votesTotal: greatly contributes to extremely high player fluctuation in the mid-tiers and an environment very unfriendly towards casual players. Woe upon the newer player daring to use the same OP builds and tactics as the veterans. For example
votesFunny: it's OK if you're getting killed by OP vet drone pooping tacklers 20 times in a row
commentsCount: but if you so much as dare using a drone in your interceptor
column16: be prepared for a veritable ♥♥♥♥♥torm.\n\n- The whole "Dreadnought" match experience is a huge hassle and pretty repetitive. Timeslots are limited
column17: setup horribly complicated
column18: and strategic sector gains are basically reserved for the vet corps due to the inherent  mechanics.\n\n- Testing of changes is reserved to/done by some of the vet players
column19: which in turn leads to  major and minor changes which generally favour the veteran player community.\n\n- Veteran players incessantly ask for more advertising to get more players (more lambs for the slaughter)
column20: not realizig that this game's primary issue is not gaining new players
column21: but to retain those who give the game a try. I have led a major corp for some time
column22: and the speed in which the game is bleeding players due to frustration is absurd (about 2% each day).\n\nOver 1.2 million players have tried this game. Only about 2k play it concurrently
column23: maybe around 7k  over the course of a week. Less than 100 vets "own" the game. Are you the one out of 10'000 that can stand the frustration and has the skill and time to make it into their ranks?\n\nIf not
column24:
give this a spin for a great casual game experience - until it's your time to rage-quit.

12/10 as Space combat game
7/10 when taking matchmaking and balancing into consideration"

reviewText: Now i'm no pro reviewer but I see alot of negtive reviews about this game I think, why? now alot of them say abusive admins but I havent experenced this myself but now onto the actual review: Is this game a pay to win? Personally I say no alot of you will disagree, sure spending money will help you progress faster but i'm used to the grind, this game reminds me of monster hunter 3 tri back on the wii in alot of ways, and just like monster hunter I was introduced to alot of frendly people who congratulated each other after a sucessful fight, people who would chat in the lobbies give useful advice to noobs (ike me) and every pre-fight we would all say stuff like stay near me so I can give you all buffs" and generally work as a team backing each other up. Now like monster hunter you feel great getting new stuff but unlike swords and armor you get ships and upgrades to these ships

reviewText:
NIce idea, bad approach.

Game play has a steep learning curve, if you can get past the curve it can be fun.

The tiers for PVE are too large, after tier 4 there is 5 ranks of ships to top of tier and all PVE encouters are based on rank 9. This mean you'll have to level most of your 4-8 ships with bonus experience.  I presume from 10-15 will be much the same.  Open world is extremely difficult under rank 6-7 and the difficulty scales up rapidly.

Modules require multiple faction credit and it costs to change factions.

Leveling without cash shop is near impossible past rank 6, and the caash shop prices are too expensive.  No micro purchases, everything is in the 5-50 dollar range.

Terrible group ques for PVP. Want to play with a group of friends, more than one will see regular 5+ minute wait times.
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The game has an interesting concept and potential but is far away from being finished (still in beta) and playable.

At first it is fun to play this space action game as it has depth and takes some strategy to win.
But soon you'll realize that this game is unbalanced, matchmaking is awful and servers are terrible.

The lack of players especially in non-Russian territories makes this game even more difficult to play with long wait times for matches.

The open beta is going on for a year or longer and the game still doesn't have a release date yet. They plan to implement more features and game modes this year and supposed to officially release the game but that all seems far away with the baby steps in development (even though they release a patch every week now but only with minor adjustments).

If you still want to play this game I recommend not spending much if any money. Don't get fooled by the progression (ship ranks) take your time to get to higher ranks and fully level/synergize all your ships.

reviewText: Star Conflict is a great space-combat game with limited three-dimensional directional control. It does have speed limiters, so it is definitely not a space simulator, but then, there don't seem to be any of those out there anyway. It has a good, dynamic upgrade system, and combat is also quite dynamic.

reviewText: Definitely worth downloading. Similar to conquest mode in Battlefield except it's in space, only better/more features and gameplay. 8.5/10 now all they need to do is let you land on planets seamlessly in real time complete with re-entry fireball effects and have ♥♥♥♥♥♥meplay on the ground or a star fox style minigame, also walking around the ships would be a nice addon. But seriously, this is actually one of the best if not hands down the very best experience I have had on the Oculus DK2. It's also easy to join up with friends. The situational awareness in VR is really good, and it stays locked at 75fps hardly any lag and no judder. Very immersive, the combat is addictive. Some interesting loot and crafting materials can be salvaged and the game universe can be explored if you undock your ship from the station as opposed to entering the PVP skirmish matchmaking countdown. Not sure if it's an MMO, but it would be a really good MMO and the ship physics are fun. Very comfortable VRexperience.

reviewText:
if your willing to dig deep into your pockets and eventually spend at least a couple hundro dollars. This game can be very satisfying. Beautiful free space sectors with various facets from treasure hunting, to very diverse questing, and even nice battles. Great PvP and PvE instances, and I mean great. But yes, you must pay lots of money!!! and you better know how to spend it because if your a noob, you could easily blow through $100.00 dollars truly believing your doing proper with it and  end up wasting every penny. I got lucky and cashed in on a 90% off ship sale, all ships. Without that I wouldn't be past tier 3 because the ships are about $40.00 each and to reach T5 you have to purchase some earlier ships. While this game is P2W, it is honestly kind of reversed. You pay first, to win later. The initial investment allows you to have a good base to earn synergy, credits and loyalty with bonuses from packs and the cash shop ships which generate extra synergy for faction ships.. Later down the road you build the ships in your faction trees, which are actually better ships. Wait, the progression ships are actually better than the $40.00 ones?  Yup, good luck getting them without the cash shop ones though. That said, there are a ton of good players in game that haven't spent a single dime and are probably the best players. (much grinding)
All that said, I really do recommend this game. Even if you dont pay a dime, you can have a lot of fun. If your willing to put some money into a game it's a good one, If your not willing to put money into this game though maybe stay away because you will like it so much you'll make poor life decisions and spend money on it anyway. Which is what I did $200.00 later.

Would spend $200.00 again and probably will.

reviewText:
Quite a learning curve to be good at this game, but upon install, one begins having fun immediately.  As with any lvl up system, the grind to new ships and equipment can be tedious at times, but once one recognizes how easily all this comes just by being active in matches, they can advance quite quickly.

The mutliple directons of movement add a dynamic that has been done before but never so well in my experience.  the ship handling FEELS good.  The game does not properly support joysticks without using a oculus rift (FoV is scaled down to less than half when using JS setup and cannot be altered...no cokcpit view, you just see the top front of your ship on the bottom 1/3rd of your screen all the time) but the keyboard controls can be customized as expected to suit your style.
*having a mouse with adjustbale dpi on the fly will help a great deal when using more than 1 type of ship and weapon in a match.

The scenery is spectacular and even more brilliant than one might 1st suspect once they disable Depth of Field...sadly, as most games do, this one loses a lot with the realistic haze" effect of DoF.

TBH

reviewText: Well i've played Star Conflict  for a while and my verdict is... A GOOD game but want you to BLEED your money hard. I played for FIVE hours straight with prem (+50%) and barely made over 2 000 000 credits and only 15 000 faction rep. (you need 75 k for ONE upgrade of 15 little things you MUST use in battle on ONE of your FOUR ships, and it's only a 3-d lvl tech) You'll need to spend about  30-45 $ monthly to play comfortably or sell your soul to a clan for five hours daily online for a year. Otherwise only grinding for tech four will take more then a two years (If you're normal person who doesn't play more then a two hours and not DAILY). It's game that flyes on a noutbook with 512 mb card on ULTRA HIGH graphics with 30 FPS, because optimization of engine and server is THAT GOOD (Robocraft I look at you) while looking like a YOBA project, but for all nine hells it's want your money bad... I'll give it positive review neverless, because it's a good game, but BE PREPARED!

reviewText:
Simply the one and only good MMOF2P space simulator out there. Deep PvP, grindy PvE, no Pay2Win and even an open world adventure for the guys like me. Eventually you might want to pay a few bucks to make things go faster, but nobody will ever really force you to do that. And if you pay, well this game deserves to be paid for.

UPD:

So I've played little more (maybe a couple of hundreds of hours more), and it's time to somewhat update this review with some new impressions and info.

First - Star Conflict is two games in one package. One game is PvP session-based tactical space shooter with huge teamwork influence and the other one is open-space based exploration game, where you just grab you ship and fly anywhere doing some missions and observing how this universe evolves from season to season. Open-space part is not very rich yet, but it grows and gets some attention from the devs with every update.

Second - some of you might think that this game is like World of Tanks with starships. Well it's not. It looks like WoT in some aspects and the hangar UI is a bit similar but the gameplay is nowhere the same. This game is ultra-fast, it requires skills and some tactical thinking. At first it's like: Hey
recommended: shooting random fellas". But play just a bit more and whenever you try to just shoot random fellas with your lazors drinking some beer you'll find yourself dead most of the times. There's really a lot to master in this game. Lots of different ship classes all with unique sets of abilities. You either learn how to use them the right way
hoursPlayed: or die again and again. And you just can't fix this by throwing in some cash. You'll just get some fancy ships instantly
voteText: but they won't complete mission objectives for ya. You can spend some bucks and get some powerful weapons faster than the free players
helpfulPercent: but it's still you who shoots them.\n\nAlso as far as I know there are no cheters here
votesHelpful: or if they are they are few and unwelcome.\n\nStill a good game after almost 600 hrs of gameplay."

reviewText: Well balanced gamed and good tutorial.  PVE, PVP, and Faction Galactic Conquest available to enjoy.  A nice set of PVE missions and PVP is filled with decent AI bots if there isn't enough players qued up.   The game is not as restrictive as Planetside 2, with cert points, but isn't overly generous either.  Probably the best progression I've experienced on a Free to Play game.   No real penalty for changing factions other than starting over with faction loyalty points but that is to be expected.  A really fun game overall, recommend you at least try so you don't miss out.
